October 20, 1949.

Mr. J.V. Boys,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hazelton, B.C.,

With reference to the applications for admission, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Alberni Indian Residential School:

Herbert Green,
Jonathan Daniel Brown
Victor Philip Brown.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

Sir,—
I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child
English name Herbert (Johnson) GREEN
Age 8 years (July 1941)
Name of Band KISILIK
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid
Father's full name and No.
Mother's full name and No.
Parents living or dead
State of child's health
Religion United Church
Does applicant speak English? New little
Previously attended school for years

(Signature of father)

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Dear Sir:

Re New Pupils to Alberni School

Application is herewith made for the admittance of the following Indian children of the Kitamaat Band to the Alberni Indian Residential School;

Robertson, Ivy Josephine 10 years
Robertson, Gordon Harvey 9 years
Robertson, Gloria Mildred 7 years

The above noted are children of Gordon and Evelyn Robertson of Kemano Village, but parents are at Butedale cannery nearly all year, where there is no chance of any children attending school.

Dorothy Woods; in this instance both parents are dead, and the girl has become somewhat of a problem. She lived for a number of years with a sister of her stepfather at Harley Bay, but about a year ago came back to Kitamaat, and lived with her grandmother, Mrs. John Bolton. Mrs. Bolton died last winter, and Mrs. Walter Wilson, another aunt took the girl, but there are already 6 children in this home, and Mrs. Wilson found that she was unable to look after Dorothy.

It is recommended that these children be admitted to Alberni Residential School.

Yours truly,

T. A. Levelton,
Assist. Supt.

December 19, 1950.

The enclosed Voucher No. 302 covers a refund of expenditures made by Mrs. Lillian Gladstone, Bella Bella Band, for transportation for herself and two children to the Alberni Residential School.

Mrs. Gladstone is employed as a ward maid at the Bella Bella Hospital and at the request of Superintendent Pruden's office, consented to act as escort for the two children referred to, to the Alberni Residential School. Although transportation was provided for the two children from Bella Bella to Nanaimo, B.C., Mrs. Gladstone was required to pay her own return fare and fares for the children by bus from Nanaimo to Alberni, B.C. She is not asking for any payment for her services as escort and there would appear to be no reason why she should have to pay her own transportation.

Mr. Pruden is receiving a copy of this letter and voucher and I would recommend that Mrs. Gladstone be reimbursed to the amount of $52.35.

W.S. Arneil,

Re: Clarence Fraser Orphan.
No. 22, Tahalimo Band.
Born November 30, 1932.

The above mentioned is a pupil in the Alberni Residential School and as we had trouble with him on the Reserve, (due to lack of care and supervision), prior to his admission to the Residential School, I considered that it would be advisable to keep him in school during the summer holidays, and suggested this to Mr. Caldwell.

I received a letter from the Principal this A.M. which says in part:

"Clarence Fraser: I would be reluctant to keep this boy for the summer. His brother has been here, first wanting to get him out for May 24th, which I did not consent to, and then wasting him out for the summer to work in a logging camp. While this boy has been amenable during his time in school, he is a different boy to what he was when he was here previously, and now has the general attitude of one with "ripe experience". He is particularly susceptible to feminine society. I question whether I could hold him in school for the summer. If it is possible, I would prefer that he be out of school."

I have no desire to impose on Mr. Caldwell as he has been most accommodating to me over the years and helped this agency out on many occasions. For that reason I do not wish to embarrass him and insist that Clarence remain during the holidays.

However, he will not be 16 years until November 30, 1951 and I am quite sure that we will not get him back again to school after the holidays, if he is allowed out. Even he is
not allowed he will likely go anyway.

In view of the information given by Mr. Caldwell on this lad, would the Department look with favour on an application for his discharge? Please advise by Air Mail.

R.H. MOORE,
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Res: Clarence Fraser, 15 years,
Roll No.22 Nanaimo Band.

The above noted orphan boy was staying with his sister,
Virginia Fraser, on the Nanaimo Indian Reserve No.1. Two weeks ago,
Virginia went to Vancouver, B.C., and left the lad to fend for himself.
Prior to her leaving, Clarence was most irregular in his school
attendance. He was also staying out late at nights, hanging around
the streets in Nanaimo, B.C.

When the matter was brought to my attention by the Nanaimo
Health Nurse, I felt immediate action should be taken and telephoned
Mr. Caldwell at Alberni Residential School, who agreed to take
Clarence as soon as I could get him there. This was done the
following day.

When I got the boy, he only had a shirt, trousers and an old
pair of shoes, to his name. This condition was not good and so I
asked Mr. Caldwell to get him some clothing which he could wear on
special occasions and Sundays, and send the accounts to me.

Mr. Caldwell supplied him with a complete outfit of everyday
or school clothes including underwear.

I would ask that the Department be good enough to pay the
attached voucher number 493, to an amount of thirty-one dollars and
ninety cents ($31.90) and have the cheque sent direct to the School
Principal, as he paid cash for the goods at Woodwards' Ltd.

Re: Admissions, Alberni Residential School.

Attached are applications for the following:
Edwina Elizabeth Nyce age 10, and Jennette Nyce age 12.
Day School attendance of these two girls has been very poor, owing to parents being away often from Kitimat in search of employment. It is felt no progress will be made unless the girls are placed in residential school. Kitimat School is also over-crowded.

Carl David Grant age 9 years. This boy is one of a family of 12 children and the home is very overcrowded. In the interests of all, it is felt advisable to remove some of the load from the family, also to relieve congestion in the school.

Alina Agatha Grant age 10 years. This home is also quite crowded and it is believed this girl and those remaining at home will all benefit by some reduction in the family load, also to relieve overcrowding of school.

Ivy Duncan age 10 years and Raymond Duncan age 11 years. The father of these two children is ill. A sister died recently of tuberculosis. There is some suspicion of malnutrition here although the children are still healthy. To make it easier for the family to cope with the younger children remaining at home, to relieve overcrowding in the school and for the general welfare of these two children the application is submitted.

Arnold Victor Mason age 16. Klemu School has been unfortunate in many ways, as a result all pupils are retarded. This boy while retarded for his years shows evidence of ability and good character. School Inspector Davey recommended that he be sent to Alberni to complete grade 8 with the hope that he might go to High School. Judging from the younger crop coming along, Klemu will need Victor as a better educated man when he reaches manhood.

It is recommended that the above children be admitted to Alberni Indian Residential School.

August 9, 1951.

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School,
Special Admissions New Westminster Agency.

Attached please find a self-explanatory letter from Mr. A. B. Caldwell, Principal of the above named Residential School.

I can readily understand that the Department would feel that the responsibility for providing clothing for the two children concerned should fall upon the administration of the Residential School, particularly if the full facts of the case were not explained when the original submission was made to the Department. It is the practice of the Alberni School, and other Residential Schools, to purchase bulk quantities of clothing in the normal sizes for children enrolled at Residential Schools. However, in this particular case both of the pupils were under school age. The Principal, upon special request, admitted these children to relieve the Department of a difficult and almost impossible task of finding accommodation for them. Had Mr. Caldwell refused to accept these children, as he was perfectly entitled to do because of their ages, and if a suitable home could have been found for them, the cost of maintenance for these children would have been considerably in excess of the amount of the per capita grant. Mr. Caldwell's action, therefore, has meant a substantial saving to the Department. I would like to say that the Principal of the Alberni Residential School has been most helpful in providing accommodation for a number of welfare cases where he was under no obligation to admit the children concerned and it is felt that he should not be penalized for so doing. As Mr. Caldwell himself states, the amount involved is small but I feel that we cannot expect to retain the very generous co-operation which we have received from Mr. Caldwell if the Department is to apply rigidly...
the regulations concerning Residential School children and to extend them to cases which do not fit into the normal pattern.

I am re-submitting this matter because I am confident that the Department's decision was reached without its having access to all of the facts.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

July 31st 1951.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Commissioner, Indian Affairs,
VANCOUVER, B.C. Re. Special Admissions
New Westminster Agency.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

I wish to bring to your attention the following:

In October last I admitted to this school at the urgent request of Mr. Gillett, Indian Superintendent for the New Westminster Agency, two boys, Frederick and Walter John, of the Soowhalie Band, then aged 5 years 7 mos and 4 years 2 mos. These children being under the school age minimum, required to have special clothes and shoes purchased for them. I requested assistance from Mr. Gillett in this matter and he asked me to furnish him with bills and he would request payment from Ottawa.

I furnished Mr. Gillet with a bill for shoes amounting to about $11.00 (the receipt has not been returned to me) and I eventually received reply with a quotation from a letter from Ottawa reading as follows:

"These pupils have been grant earning pupils at the Alberni Residential School since October 1950. This account should, therefore, be paid by the Principal".

Mr. Gillet assures me that he explained the situation in his letter to Ottawa. This is a comparatively small matter, but I have tried to co-operate with the Department in the taking of these necessitous cases, cases that would present a serious problem, and no inconsiderable expense to the Department if they were not cared for by the school, and my inclination is to continue such co-operation. However, as you may know, our present Government revenue is some 22 points below the cost of living index, and it is only reasonable to expect co-operation from the Department, at least in these special cases.

Yours sincerely,

Attached are applications for admission to Alberni Residential School on behalf of the following children whose departure from here will relieve overcrowding of the senior room Bella Coola Day School.

Arthur Hens, age 14, Grade 4. There are six younger children in this home, where income is quite low. It is believed both this boy and the younger children will benefit by this reduction of the family load.

Vincent Gordon Hens, age 10, Grade 4. There is a good deal of drinking in this boy's home. An older brother is an incorrigible delinquent. A still older boy who was trained at Alberni is much above the family average in character and stability and it is felt this younger boy should have advantage of residential school training.

Norman Hens, age 14, Grade 4. The attendance of this boy has been poor. Both teacher and parents complain that he is hard to manage. I do not believe he is a really bad boy, but is much bigger than other children in the school. Twenty-four hour discipline and more sports activity in residential school will I believe make a good man of this lad.

Mr. Caldwell has been good enough to allow places for these boys, who will leave here as soon as escort can be arranged.

W.P. Redden

ALBERNI, B.C.

Jan. 10th 1952.

Mr. N.W. Garrard,
Indian Superintendent,
PORT ALBERNI, B.C. Re. Discharges, December Quarter.

Dear Mr. Garrard,

You will note comment against several names of girls of High School standing:- "See Letter".

In September last six girls were admitted to this school from Skidegate, Queen Charlotte Islands, to attend High School. Two of these had been attending school at Prince Rupert. Just why they were transferred to this school I do not know, except that perhaps their parents considered the supervision at Prince Rupert was not satisfactory. It was very evident that they had had a great amount of freedom there, more than it was possible to give them here at the residential school.

These girls set themselves out to be as much of a nuisance as possible, abusing every privilege, smoking, absenting themselves without leave and generally rebellious. Unfortunately, the new High School did not open until October 1st, but gave the girls a month or so after the school opened to settle down. They had completely unsettled several of the other High School girls and there was a general break-down of discipline that threatened to completely disrupt the school.

I finally had to take the matter up with Mr. Findlay, Superintendent, Massett, and with Mr. Davey, and came to the conclusion that the only thing to do was to discharge these girls and some others who had become unruly beyond the point of reform.

I am pleased to say that the situation then improved and we are back to the normal good behaviour of the High School pupils.

I regret having to take this action, and did not do so until it was unavoidable.

Yours very truly,

Re: Admissions Alberni Indian Residential School.

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of December 27, 1951, the last Quarterly Return covering the period ending December 31, 1951 for the above named school indicates that the average enrolment for that quarter has been 239 pupils. The Principal has been urged by several of the Superintendents to admit about six additional pupils who are necessitous cases but the Principal will be discharging several children whose home conditions now permit them to return. It is anticipated that the average should remain around the 240 mark. The school can adequately handle this number.

W. S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Extract from Social Worker's Report for the month of October, 1951.

These six girls were previously referred to in the August report when they came to Vancouver en route to Alberni School and separated themselves from the escort. They are all fairly mature high school girls with modern ideas. After being in the school approximately a month, Mr. Caldwell, principal of the school, felt that their behaviour was such that they could not remain at Alberni, and arrangements were made for their return home. Upon being met at the airport in Vancouver, three of the girls - Betty Russ, Dolores Jones and Ann Williams - refused to return home, and stated that they had made plans to remain in Vancouver. The parents of the girls were advised and the woman with whom the girls were staying was interviewed regarding the responsibility she was taking on without authority from the girls' parents. Although this woman appeared quite sincere and a responsible woman, and was already acquainted with one of the girls, Ann Williams, who had boarded with her previously, she was extremely hostile to the Indian Department owing to complaints by the girls about school. Her intention was to do "a full scale investigation" regarding the atrocious conditions permitted in a government supported school. Although it was felt that the girls' complaints were in some cases unfounded and others greatly magnified, it was felt advisable to satisfy this woman, Mrs. Smythe, rather than ignoring her attitude, therefore, a conference was held with worker, Mrs. Smythe, Major Davey and the girls to give them an opportunity of expressing their complaints. As a result of this interview, it was quite apparent that the girls' complaints were merely a symptom of rebellion against a discipline to which they had not been accustomed. By agreement with the parents, arrangements were made for the girls to remain with Mrs. Smythe and attend school in Vancouver. One girl was subsequently returned home at the request of her family.

Dear Major MacKay,

I have received a letter from the local Agency in connection with the admission here (at the request of the Indian Superintendent) of Lillian Alice Olebar, Elizabeth Ann Olebar, and Georgina Olebar, last September.

The father of these children, deceased, was Catholic. In the letter it is noted that the following ruling has been made: "Applicant being Roman Catholic, children should attend Roman Catholic School", and I am instructed to discharge these pupils at the end of this academic year.

In this case, while I believe the application stated that the children were Catholic, the Mother (who is the applicant) is, and always has been, Protestant. While her husband was alive the children had attended a day-school, and later at the expense of the Department. The applicant refused to send her children to the Catholic School and I accepted them on application being made here at Alberni.

On enquiry re the August children (2) who had been taken into the Catholic School after the mother (a Catholic) had placed them here for a year (these children had been baptised Protestant, the deceased father having been Protestant), I am told that these pupils can remain in the Catholic school as the mother is Catholic. I take no exception to this ruling, but should not the same ruling apply to the Olebar children, whose mother, the applicant, is Protestant? The mother is a Campbell, from Ahousat, and we have had all the Campbell children as pupils. Further, Mr. Garrard tells me that the mother was never legally married to her Catholic husband, now deceased.

Would you please give this ruling further consideration in view of the above facts?

Yours sincerely,

Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Indian Branch Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs:

Re Addmissions Alberni Residential School.

Attached are forms of application for admission for the following:

Donald Footlass, 13 years, grade IV
Lorrain Footlass, 8 years, grade III
Dayl Footlass, 9 years, grade IV
Leonard Abel Footlass, 6 years, beginner.

All of the above are children of Mr. Alex Footlass of the Bella Coola Band.

Mr. Footlass's wife left him last fall. He cared for the children as well as he could during last winter. He has two children under school age and two who are dependent over school age.

Mrs. Footlass appears at Bella Coola frequently and stays with her own relatives. She is a very poor mother. Her influence on the children is not good. The school age children would be much better off in every way at the Residential School.

I recommend that approval for their admission be granted.

W.P. Fruden, Supt.,
Bella Coola Indian Agency,
Bella Coola, B.C.

Sir:

I beg leave to submit for your consideration the following report on Manual Training at the Indian Residential School, Alberni for the year ending June 30th, 1928.

During the year, 23 classes were held showing a total working period of 232½ hours; all work was done in spare time.

The type of instruction was of two kinds. The smaller boys were given a course much the same as that given to first year boys in the Manual Training School at Vancouver—simple models for benchwork and drawing; for the larger boys who had taken the beginners' course the previous year a more practical course was arranged; drawing was confined to rough sketches and designs or the drawing of patterns on brown paper.

The first project was the construction of three benches 6' x 3'; these were good strong carpenter workbenches giving ample room for two boys working at alternate corners. Designs for tool racks were submitted by the boys and the one considered the best was the one used. The below partial list of articles made will show the nature of the course.

Hospital tables 4', kitchen tables with drawer, cutting boards for kitchen use, pastry boards, axe handles, drawing boards and T squares, door handles, photo and picture frames, towel rollers, flower boxes, book shelves, toothbrush racks, benches for dining-room, bob-sleighs, wall brackets, tabouret tables, and teapot stands.

The boys have been praised for the quality of their work by visitors to the school; you, sir, have while on visits of inspection, seen the work.

I much regret that during the last two months the classes have not been as regular as they might have been; I found the extra work very trying on my health; for this same reason the contemplated boat building was not commenced.

As I am leaving this school I must hereby tender my resignation as Instructor; I thank you very sincerely for your kindness and help.

I am, yours respectfully,

George Johnson,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of Department letter No. 1895/26/1, dated Ottawa September 27th, re Mr Inspector Cairns recommendation for manual training for pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School, with your instructions to report on the same. I beg to advise the Department that the matter was taken up with Mr Inspector Cairns some months ago and suggestions were presented to Mr Commissioner Pritchburn for his perusal and remarks; the matter was also taken up with the Mission authorities connected with the school, all of whom declared themselves thoroughly in accord with the suggestion, but apparently the time was not then opportune for action to be taken.

The old class room, a separate building used for class room purposes prior to the building of the present school is available as a manual training workshop. It provides a room 30 feet by 22 by 10, is in good repair having been newly shingled and painted, is amply provided with windows and heating facilities, but would need to be wired for electric lighting if evening classes approved.

Mr Johnson the senior teacher is prepared to give three lessons each week, two evening lessons of two hours each and one lesson each Saturday morning of three hours, all lessons to be given in his own time after ordinary classroom work. The remuneration suggested, to be $200.00 per year.

Mr Johnson attended the Summer School of instruction in manual training during the past summer, to keep in touch with up to date methods.

There are 21 pupils at the Alberni Indian Residential School, between the ages of 13 and 18 years, these could be divided into 3 classes for instruction, each class could be given one lesson per week.

Should the Department approve and provide for manual training for the pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School, I respectfully beg to suggest that that training should take precedence to farming instruction and that the Principal be so advised.

A list of tools and materials necessary for the instruction of a class of six and fitting up of the building, is enclosed herewith, with approximate cost of same.

EXTRACT from Report of G.H. Barry, Inspector of Schools for B.C., dated June 10 & 11, 1931, regarding his inspection of the ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 159-1-6.

MANUAL TRAINING:

In addition to the work on the farm, the boys learn to make such things as clock cases, tables, book shelves, chairs, etc. Twenty boys are taking this course. They do not follow the proper Manual Training Course, as their teacher Mr. A. Glen, has no certificate. He is able to teach the boys rough carpenter's work; but could not instruct in the more scientific Manual Training. The shop at present in use is situated under the primary classroom. It is about 40 ft. by 25 ft. There are 4 double benches.

I should like to see these boys taught real Manual Training. The difficulty seems to be that the City schools do not employ a Manual Training Instructor, who could put in some of his time with this class. The Principal seems to think that he would not be able to pay a trained teacher in this subject. I explained to him that the Department was very anxious that Manual Training should be taught in the Indian Residential Schools and were prepared to help in various ways.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE
P.O. BOX 665
VICTORIA, B.C. June 26, 1931.

Dear Sir:

I am submitting herewith report of School Inspector Barry in regard to the Indian Residential School at Alberni.

In connection with the Inspector's remarks on manual training it will be noted he feels the pupils should receive more advanced teaching along this line than they are at present receiving from Mr. Glenn, who is really the farmer, but the Principal thinks he cannot afford to employ a manual training instructor. It will be noted in the staff list that Mr. Glenn is in receipt of a salary of $720.00 per annum with part board and lodging, which salary is to my mind little enough for the work he has to do on the farm. It will also be noted on the financial statement that this school is in receipt of a grant of $480.00 per annum for manual training. This amount apparently goes toward paying the salary of Mr. Glenn, who is described as besides being a farmer nothing more than a rough carpenter, who gives a certain amount of carpentry instruction to the pupils in the evenings, and as the case is now it really means that $480.00 which we pay towards the salary of a competent manual training teacher really goes to pay about 2/3rds of the salary of the farmer, the balance of $240.00 being paid by the school. Apparently what is really needed at this school is a disciplinarian for the boys and if one with a fair knowledge of manual training could be secured, the intentions of the Department in regard to manual training would be much more efficiently carried out than is now the case.

As regards the fire escape, your file 109-1-5 contains full information with regard to the same. It would however do no harm, and be of small expense, to have Inspector Barry's suggestion carried out.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mrs. Spotton:

Yours of the 15th instant just to hand re Inspector Barry's recommendation for the appointment of a qualified manual training instructor. I am indeed pleased that this matter has been taken up through the general offices of the church. Allow me to go into the matter thoroughly that you may understand the situation and decide accordingly.

Mr. Glen is farm instructor and also manual training instructor. He had worked at carpenter work for six years before coming to the school. During the last year he has done some very good cabinet work with the boys in manual training. Re. Mr. Glen's salary as stated in the letter of the Department is $720.00. The type written statement of salaries I gave to Inspector Barry was farm and manual training instructors salary $720.00 with part board, free house, partly furnished, free water, free fuel and free electric light, approximately $1100. With all these things free the salary is worth $1200.00 - $480. Is the special grant for the manual training. The Department should not have said they were paying two thirds of his salary.

The statement that he gives a certain amount of carpentry instruction to the boys in the evening is not correct. Seven senior boys made up the class Wed- 7-9 P.M. Nine intermediate boys Friday 3-5 P.M. and nine junior boys Sat. 9-11 A.M. These classes were followed out regularly. As the work took the farm instructor away from farm work practically all of Friday afternoon and Saturday forenoon I do not think that the $480.00 more than paid for the service in this department. Three years ago I had a qualified manual training instructor as senior teacher. The Department paid him 75 cents per hour for any kind of work. The result was that my teacher went to Technical School in Vancouver for this work at $2000.00 per year. The city of Alberni with four class room teachers - Port Alberni with eight teachers and high school with four teachers are near us. Acting with Mr. Kyle, Supervisor of Technical Education in British Columbia, I tried to arrange with these school boards to get a teacher between us for this work but these boards would not on the ground that they could not afford it.

In a letter to the Department through Mrs. Clark, dated Oct. 14th 1921, I pointed out that we could not do much at Manual Training so along as the boys were allowed to leave school at 16 years. We have no boys over 16, our list shows only 6 above 14 years and one of these was drowned since holidays,
8 boys 14 yrs. and 6 boys 13 yrs. If these big schools in the towns cannot afford a manual training teacher it hardly seems fair that the Department should ask us to get a Technical teacher for 19 young boys between 13 and 16 years. Of course, I would be pleased to have an extra man on the staff to take some of the work and responsibility off me but an extra man for this work means another $1200.00 or $1500.00 at least, from the church. In view of the present conditions in our church and country I am not prepared to recommend this expenditure.

I engage a missionary staff who work for less and do work they would not otherwise do, because it is church work, we run the school with the strictest possible economy to keep down expense and yet even with this self sacrificing, hard work and econom, the per capita grant covers only about two thirds of the expense of the school. I paid to three qualified, trained in Manual Training teachers with three or four years experience total $2280.00 with board. Yet with this careful management and the church furnishing one third of the expense, the Inspector points out repairs to the large building and equipment and I am instructed to have these repairs made and pay for it out of school funds. This happened a day or two ago in a letter from Secretary McKenzie of the Indian Department instructing me to have the 84 horsepower heating boiler overhauled during holidays and pay for out of per capita grantor other school funds.

I would be pleased to see a copy of the contract or agreement between the church and the Department about the management of these schools. If there is any expense for typing it I will pay for it.

I shall be glad to hear the decision of your Board as to securing a qualified Manual training instructor. As there are none available, except carpenters, outside the cities of Victoria or Vancouver, and the work would be for only a few hours each week, it is not easy to reorganize our work to use such a member of staff unless he works at something else as well as Manual training.

Yours sincerely,

Sgd. F.G. Pitts.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his visit to the ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on April 26th, 1932. Original on File 159-1-6.

Vocational Training:

In addition to the ordinary house work, the girls learn to mend, darn, make dresses, make boys' shirts, knit, crochet, etc. The embroidery and fancy needlework are very good indeed. The girls do not make bread at this school. They take it in turns to learn to cook.

In addition to work on the farm, the boys are doing some sort of Manual Training under a new teacher, Mr. G. Lundine. This man is reported to be a cabinet maker. He takes three classes per week, two lessons being given on Fridays and one on Saturdays. Each lesson lasts for two hours. There are 19 boys in the Manual Training Classes, which had only just been started under the present teacher when I inspected the school. The teacher is paid $5.00 per week. I understand that the farm instructor, who is leaving at the end of the school year, is also being paid for Manual Training which he is not doing. The Principal was not able to explain this to my satisfaction but I gathered that he had given the Farm Instructor something of a contract which he could not get out of.

Six drawing boards are required for the use of the class. These should be paid for by the school in my opinion, in view of the fact that the Department makes a larger grant to the school than is being used for suitable Manual Training. The Manual Training shop in use is situated under the Primary schoolroom. It is about 40 feet by 25 feet, and there are 4 double benches.

I should like to see a proper Manual Training instructor employed at this school. I have been in touch with the Director of Manual Training and Technical Instruction for the Province of B.C. and am informed that there are available a number of partly trained M.T. instructors, who are also teachers and belong to the United Church of Canada. One of these men could easily be selected who would be able to teach the senior grades, and instruct in Manual Training. If a girl is preferred as teacher, such a man might well take the position of Boys' supervisor, and be responsible for the boys when out of school and not with any other teacher or instructor.

I am not satisfied with the new arrangement for the Manual Training on the grounds that the teacher does not hold as far as I can learn any sort of certificate and does not appear to me to have much idea of what is required, and also because the money paid by the Department does not appear to be used for the purposes intended and specified under the heading Manual Training Instructor.

I would ask the Department not to do anything in the matter till I have the opportunity of again inspecting this school in September of this year. I am so much dissatisfied with the general administration of the school that I particularly wish for the opportunity of again inspecting before making a definite recommendation to the Department. I have had a short conference with the Rev. Arthur Barner with regard to the school, and have informed the Principal that, had it not been for the fact that the school was so much cleaner than had been the case on the occasion of my inspection last year, I would not have hesitated to ask the Department to request the United Church of Canada to make a change in the administration of the school, by the appointment of a new Principal.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of Feb. 28th #159-1-11, I beg to report as follows:

Rev. F. E. Pitts, Principal—Graduate in Arts and Theology and ordained minister of former Presbyterian Church, now of the United Church, 63 years of age. Has charge of the religious teaching and services of the school, supervisor of all departments, management of the farm, recruiting and discharging of the children and full responsibility for all matters of discipline, finance, reports to the Department and all office work.

Mrs. Pitts, Matron in charge is 60 years of age. Graduate of Alexandria and Oshawa Colleges and gold medallist in music. Has supervision of all the ladies' departments of work and instruction. Teaches instrumental music to about 30 children individually and singing to all collectively, and jointly with the principal looks after the health, nursing of the children and religious services. Gives out all supplies of food, shoes, clothing and material for laundry, sewing room and kitchen.

Mr. Lawrence Wallace, Senior Classroom Teacher, age 21. Second year university and normal training.

Miss Laura Lane, Intermediate Teacher, age 30. Grade XII (1st class) normal training.

Miss Ethel Pitts, Primary Teacher, age 27. Grade XII (1st class) normal training, music, and primary certificates.

Miss Grace Lewman, Seamstress, age 28. Grade XI and normal training. Teaches needlework, dressmaking etc.

Miss Clara McLeod, age 45. Stenographer and clerk. Teaches laundry work very efficiently.

Miss Blanche Muir, age 32, very efficient cook and manager in the kitchen. Teaches the girls, cooking and baking and all housework in that department.

Miss Ruby Clark, Boys Matron, age 28. Has some training in nursing. Looks after the boys side of the building, boys' clothing, etc.

Mr. Ernest Muir, Farm Instructor, age 31. Raised on a farm. Had 2 years in Manitoba Agricultural College, Winnipeg. Trained in military aeroplane flying. Teaches the boys the farm work, milking, care of stock etc.
Mr. Gus Lundine, Manual Training Instructor is a ship-carpenter and a good practical teacher and gives the boys very careful instruction in all kinds of carpenter work, making diagrams of the work. The boys furnished a very creditable collection for Vancouver Pacific Exhibition last August. 21 boys divided in classes of 7 each take 2 hours per week each in this class.

It is difficult to specify how many hours per week each pupil has been engaged in each department and to say definitely what each has accomplished as all these have to be varied according to the age, health and strength of the child. The pupils of 14 years and over except those in the entrance class are working in these departments for the half day. They are changed every two months from one department to another so that each child gets training in all the departments. All children vary in what they accomplish. Our boys in the first years when they stay in till 18 years of age are able to handle a team, milk, care for stock and do nearly any kind of farm work that a boy can be expected to do. They have also a pretty good knowledge of handling tools for carpenter work. Of course tradesmen are not turned out at 18 years whether white or Indian. The girls at 18 have a pretty thorough knowledge of the work of cooking, baking, dressmaking, knitting, needlework and general housework and are very efficient at it. When we need extra labor we always engage ex-pupils and find them more satisfactory than any white help we could get.

One of the difficulties in managing an Indian School is to find a staff who know the work in the departments better than the senior pupils.

These towns of Alberni and Port Alberni have a large school population in public and high schools. A great many of the parents have said to me that the children of the Indian School get a much better all-round training than their children do.

Under general remarks I have only to say that the children are bright and teachable, interested in their work and do their work remarkably well. They do this even knowing that when they go out from school the things we have taught them they will have no chance to use.

Do the results justify the expenditure? At the time they go out of school, yes, decidedly yes. Ten years later it may be doubtful. The fault is not theirs. It is not the school course that needs change so much as the conditions to which they go when they leave school.

We endeavour to teach the pupils farming, gardening, milking and anything that would be useful to them after they leave school. It is difficult to teach the girls milking, gardening and outdoor work as it requires special clothes just for this, extra supervision, cows go dry quickly with too many youngsters milking.

I think the present school course is well adapted to develop the Indian child to the position where he or she can fit into our present civilization. Two factors, not generally taken into account work against the best results. First, the Indian thinks he is disloyal to his own race if he is too much like a "white man," and second, the "white man" won't give the Indian a job or position on the same terms and standing as if he were white. It will take a couple of generations to overcome both of these.

Yours obediently,

Ottawa, February 20, 1937.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

I am deeply interested in vocational education and in ways and means whereby vocational instruction can be extended in our schools.

A few weeks ago, the Minister of the Department, while speaking in the House, expressed the view that the instruction given in our Indian schools would have to become gradually and steadily more vocational in character.

In making a brief study of departmental reports, I have encountered a report sent in to the Department by you, dated April 12th, 1934. It would appear that, at that time, you had made provision at the Alberni Residential School for instruction in elementary agriculture, carpentry work, etc. I notice, also, that year, you sent in a very creditable collection to the Vancouver Pacific Exhibition.

I am anxious to know just what progress has been made since then and if you have any information at your disposal, in respect to the progress made by pupils who received this training, during the years following their departure from school. I am aware, of course, that the facilities at your disposal are far from perfect. Any information, however, you can let me have along the lines suggested would be very much appreciated.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We are gradually getting settled in the new school and trying to perfect our staff and school organization in order to secure best results for the balance of the school year. We appreciate very much the assistance the Department has given us in establishing this school and making the transfer from Coqualeetza, and I assure you of my earnest desire to co-operate in every way in forwarding the plans of the Department for Indian education upon the West Coast.

In the rush of work which has been upon me, I am not sure that I have thanked you for your letter of August 6th last. File:159-1-11. In this letter arrangements were made for the salaries in the Manual Training Department, for an instructor at $75 a month, an assistant instructor at $40 a month and a boat builder at $50 a month.

As much of the time until Christmas will be used in construction work, it may not be possible for us to use an assistant Manual Training instructor. I have been wondering if for this school year, the Department would allow me to substitute for this assistant Manual Training instructor, the salary of a baker. I have a fully qualified baker who will take charge of the equipment in our bakehouse. A many of these boys, and all of our present sixteen year old boys, will be employed in the fishing industry and most of them on seine boats. The knowledge of baking and cooking is very essential. I did not want to convert this $40 a month without having taken the matter up with you. As I have just said, I am quite sure that it would round out the technical instruction and the navigation given to these boys, if they could at the end of the year, be able to take the position of cook on a seine boat. I would undertake to see that these sixteen year old boys got a real grounding in baking bread, etc.

It would be understood of course, that this would not set a precedent for next year, but that the matter of this grant for an Assistant Manual Training instructor should be taken up before the beginning of the next school year. From the standpoint of school finance, when so many extra expenses have to be absorbed due to the need for work and equipment which can not wait to be submitted to Ottawa, and owing to the increased...
prices which we have to pay for commodities, it would be of decided assistance in carrying on for the next eight months.

Again thanking you for your interest and assistance in all these things, and awaiting your valued reply, I am,

Yours sincerely

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the amounts promised for instructors in the manual training department at the Alberni Indian Residential School.

I note your suggestion that the amount promised for an assistant instructor be allowed toward the salary of the baker. While I appreciate that a baking course for the older boys who will engage in the fishing industry is very essential at the same time it is impossible for us to allow any amount toward the baker's salary.

My understanding of your letter is that the baker employed on the school staff to do the cooking for the whole institution would give special lessons to the boys who are to engage in the fishing industry. If we allowed any amount toward his salary it would mean that we would be assisting in paying the salary of a member of the staff whom it is necessary to employ and as you are aware the salaries of necessary members of the staff are paid by the school management from per capita grants or other receipts. With this in mind I feel that you will readily realize that it is not possible to favourably consider your request.

Yours truly,

West Coast Agency,

January 31, 1941.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular Agency letter covering conditions within this Agency during the month ending January 31st, 1941.

School:

Alberni Residential School was visited several times during the month. The dormitories, classrooms, dining rooms and kitchens were all in first class order. Basement, classroom hallways and toilets were not very clean and were untidy.

The enamel ware (cups, saucers and plates) have not been replaced and are very unsanitary and unsightly.

The health of the school is fair. Seven cases of trachoma were found, one of jaundice and a few of tonsillitis. All trachoma cases were pupils from other agencies, and none from the West Coast.

Good progress is being made in classrooms. The pupils are attentive, well behaved, and well clothed. Good substantial meals are being served.

Grounds, outhouses, boiler room and laundry were all in good order. Fire extinguishers have been provided.

The girls are being well taught in needlework and domestic science, but not much evidence of vocational training for boys was noted. Some were getting training in dairying and agriculture, which is of little or no value to West Coast Indians, and others were doing rough carpentry.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant with reference to boat building tools requested by the Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School. You may arrange for the purchase of the tools required and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. I attach the quotations which you received. When forwarding the voucher covering the cost of these tools you should attach your purchase order. An encumbrance will be secured when the account reaches Ottawa.

I am also in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant enclosing a further list of tools required for the vocational training classes at this school. As the end of the fiscal year is rapidly approaching and there are some funds still available authority is granted for you to purchase additional tools for the vocational training classes at a cost not exceeding $495.00. The account should be dated previous to March 31, 1941, and when forwarding it for payment you should attach a copy of your purchase order. An encumbrance will be secured when the account reaches here. You understand, of course, that the purchase order for the tools to the value of $495.00 should be separate from the one for the tools purchased for the boat building class. I am also enclosing the quotations which you received on this additional equipment.

It is our intention to direct another letter to you under separate cover in connection with the vocational training at the Alberni School.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I attach voucher No. 482 just received from Indian Agent Ashbridge. While the total amount of the voucher is $404.25 there is included an amount of $225.00 for the services of the manual training instructors. Authority has already been given for the engagement of these men but it would be preferred in future if a separate voucher were issued in favour of the Principal covering their services. This voucher should read -- "To allowance toward services of vocational training instructors at Alberni Residential School for the month of ..........".

My particular reason in returning the voucher to you is that it includes two expenditures, one covering the cost of goods purchased from the Alberni Pacific Lumber Co., at a cost of $57.79, and the other an account of A. McDonald & Sons for $121.46. While the Principal's letter explains quite fully what use was made of the material purchased and I have no doubt that the building mentioned was required, at the same time our files do not show that any authority was given for the purchase of the items covered by these two accounts. As you will easily realize, it is impossible for us to keep control of expenditures if Rev. Mr. Scott assumes the power to purchase over $175.00 worth of material without any authority.

If you agree with the statements made by Rev. Mr. Scott in his letter of January 20, it would

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
be appreciated if you would issue purchase orders in favour of the two firms mentioned above. At the same time you should instruct Mr. Ashbridge to the effect that a separate voucher should be forwarded in future for the allowance for the salaries of the vocational training instructors. At the same time you should point out definitely both to Mr. Ashbridge and Rev. Mr. Scott that in future unauthorized purchases at the Alberni Residential School cannot be paid by this Branch.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Some years ago, Mr. Jones of Ahousaht had a boat built, which he called the "Dawn." It seems to have been in some way tied up with the School. The Woman's Missionary Society transferred it to Alberni, where it is in the care of Captain Scott, who will use it in connection with his work and also in helping the boys learn navigation. He has not been able to get registration of the boat for lack of certain documents, the first of which is a Bill of Sale to The United Church of Canada from the builder. This boat was built by Mr. Jones when he was at the Ahousaht School, and the suggestion is that the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs should give a Bill of Sale to The United Church of Canada for the nominal sum of One Dollar. Could you arrange that this be done? If so, I should be glad to get this document as soon as possible, as Captain Scott cannot run the boat until he gets registration, and naturally the customs officers are very strict in these days of war.

Dear Sir:

The former Ahousaht Indian Residential School was located at Ahousaht on the west coast of Vancouver Island, approximately 75 miles north of Port Alberni.

The Ahousaht Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire in January, 1940, and instead of replacing it we erected a new Indian residential school at Alberni. This Indian residential school is managed for us by the United Church of Canada.

Some years ago pupils of the Ahousaht School, under the direction of the Principal, built a boat which was called "The Dawn". The Principal of the Alberni School, Rev. R.C. Scott, advises that this boat has been transferred to the Alberni Residential School but he has been unable to get registration of it owing to lack of certain documents.

In view of the fact that both the Ahousaht School and the Alberni School are Government institutions and both of them have been managed for us by the United Church of Canada, there does not appear to be any reason why Rev. Mr. Scott should experience any difficulty in registering the boat.

With the above facts in mind, I should appreciate your advising what procedure he should follow to obtain registration.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of August 18th, File:159-1-11, enclosing copy of a letter which you received from the Reverend George Dorey, D.D., with regard to the registration of the M.V. Dawn.

I beg to say that I am forwarding today by Air Mail the Bill of Sale which you sent me a few days ago. I quite understand the difficulty in which all parties have been placed by the failure of the Reverend Mr. Jones to complete the registration of the boat at the time it was built. Just why he did not do it, I do not of course know. At this late date we are in difficulties.

As the materials were given by the Department to the former Ahousaht School for a Manual Training project and the engine donated to that school, it would seem that the Department would be right in giving the Bill of Sale to the United Church. The project was completed by the Reverend Mr. Jones at the former Ahousaht school in due course. The boat was much too large to be used by the missionary of the United Church so the Women's Missionary Society agreed to transfer it to this school, to allow the Principal of the school to keep in touch with the villages on Alberni Canal and Barclay Sound from which pupils come.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from Dr. Dorey. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

It would be appreciated if you would send forward to Dr. Dorey the Bill of Sale referred to in his communication.

I must express regret that so much delay has occurred in the registration of this boat. I frankly become disgusted from time to time with the amount of documents that have to be signed and the amount of correspondence that has to take place in such comparatively simple transactions as the transfer of a small boat from one school to another. I have learned from experience, however, that it is exceedingly difficult to focus responsibility in such cases. Red tape with all its attendant evils has existed for a long time in this country and is likely to continue long after you and I have made our contribution and passed on. It does seem to me regrettable however, that it should be so much in evidence in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves.

Reverend Sir:

Dr. Dorey has forwarded to us a form in connection with the motor vessel "Dawn". One of our officials interviewed the Director of Marine Services, Department of Transport, and was informed that the following documents had to be prepared and forwarded before any action could be taken:

1. Builder's Certificate, signed by the manual training instructor under whose supervision the vessel was built, or, if this is not available, a statutory declaration stating why it cannot be produced and naming the builder and for whom the vessel was built;

2. A Bill or Bills of Sale from the first owner to the present applicant for registry;

3. Tonnage Formula and Certificate of Survey;

4. Application for Registry;

5. Declaration of Ownership;

6. Declaration of Assets -- bond or other security;

7. Form RS23A, being application for name.

I am further advised that the necessary forms for the above purposes can be obtained from the local office of the Department of Transport either in Victoria or Vancouver.

I return the document which was forwarded for signature as it cannot be completed until the other documents are signed.

REPORT ON WEST COAST AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1943.

Schools:

Alberni Residential School was visited and found in fair order. Constant changes of staff appear to keep the school in a state of disorganization.

Lack of supervision is very noticeable in the boys, who apparently do as they like and who have a very dirty and slovenly appearance, both in and out of class. Three boys were found on the nearby reserve during school hours, and four were in the workshop playing with a circular saw without supervision.

No manual training of value is being carried out, beyond the usual chores and the domestic work of the girls.

While it is understood that changes in staff create difficulties, there is a great need of organizations and supervision at this school.

Two cases of chicken pox have developed in the past week and these have been isolated.

Ottawa, November 8, 1944.

Mr. A.E. Caldwell, Principal, Alberni Residential School, Alberni, British Columbia.

I regret that your letter of October 12th, has not yet been answered any sooner. I wished to consult Mr. Doucet before answering this letter and he has been away on inspection trips making it impossible to do so before the present time.

British Columbia has not been organized in the same manner as the other provinces as regards the Manual Training. Manual Training has been organized for quite some time in your province due to the British Columbia special grant. Supervision of this work was left in the hands of Inspector Barry and on his retirement in care of the Provincial Inspector. For the time being, the Department does not wish to interfere in this set-up. We therefore, suggest that you consult school inspector Manning in this respect.

It is with the understanding that the above suggestions will be followed that I am sending all the material that we have so far developed in Manual Training.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
October 12th, 1944.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We are undertaking as complete a vocational training programme as possible this year, and to facilitate this activity, we wish to receive the various record sheets and report forms (for monthly use) for the different courses.

We understand that there are more specific outlines for manual training, other than the itemized basic operations for each of the three years, which include blueprints and similar helps. We would appreciate receiving this material, and any helps for the other courses which may have been prepared as guides for instructors.

Sincerely yours,

A.E. CALDWELL
Principal

Re: Manual Training

January 24th 1946.

Dear Sir,

I have yours of the 7th Inst., re our neglect in the forwarding of reports on work accomplished by manual training.

In looking back for an explanation of this neglect, I find that the Manual Instructor, who came to me when I first took over at Alberni, from Manitoba, was not aware of the necessity for sending the monthly report. The office clerical assistance changed also at the same time and the matter was neglected by the office. While keeping in close personal touch with the really excellent work that has been done by the manual instructor, the matter of the neglect to make monthly reports was not brought to my attention until I received your letter.

Fortunately, the instructor, who has had teaching experience among the Indians of Northern Manitoba, is very methodical, has been following the complete Department course, adding thereto some of the High School manual instruction, and has kept complete records of the grading and progress of all pupils. Thus we have been able to compile a complete report since he took over. I may say the work was inspected by Dr. Morrison, Provincial School Inspector, at the end of last term.

The Manual Training rooms, I understand, were originally under the class-room building that was burned in 1941. The present accommodation, in the boat-house, is very inadequate, and boys of all age groups could not be accommodated. The new class-rooms will be constructed this year and we hope that provision is being made for vocational instruction in the building.

Much work has been done on the school grounds by the Manual classes. Old buildings have been moved to more convenient locations, swings, teetors, and horizontal bars have been erected. During last fall, the harvesting of about 100 tons of potatoes was in charge of the instructor and his classes. We hope to extend the scope of the classes when the new class-rooms are built, and have in mind the instruction in boat-building that was a feature of Coqualeetza.

Yours very Truly,

Principal
A. E. CALDWELL

ALBERNI, B.C.

June 28th 1946.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Many thanks for your letter of May 21st re the salary of the vocational instructor. I have delayed answering it until now as I have been undecided as to just what to do. I think I have finally solved the problem. Mr. Loewen wishes to keep in the employment of the school, but he intends to get married and we have no accommodation on the ordinary staff for married people. Mr. Loewen, in addition to being a good manual instructor, sports organizer, etc., is, as I have occasion to know at Norway House, an excellent Farm Instructor.

As you may know, I took over this school under poor financial circumstances. There were several causes, mainly the fact that pupils were not returned to school at the beginning of the term, particularly the local pupils, many being away in the States berry and hop picking. This financial loss, amounting to upwards of $2000.00 a year, I eliminated at once by excluding (after sufficient warning) some 30 tardy pupils, admitting in their place some of the many waiting applications for entrance. This effectively blocked that leakage, and although I have since re-admitted many of the then excluded pupils, I have had no recurrence of tardiness.

Another leakage was the so-called "farm" operations, and this has taken longer to overcome. Our farm operations were laborious, working about 15 acres of indifferent land with three horses and a very poor outfit of machinery. About 6 or 7 cows were being milked. All feed was purchased (and this is expensive in B.C.) and no pasture was obtainable. Our best potato crop was 7½ tons in 1946, and we use approximately 40 tons a year. It required two farmers to work this land and look after the cattle, and these were a legacy left from the previous administration. Their methods were poor, but, during the war time, they had to be put up with. Last year I rented more land and borrowed a tractor for a time, with the result that farm operations were an asset instead of a liability as previously. Our potato crop last year was about 70 tons, although part of this was lost by a blight that affected all B.C. potato crops. However, we had enough potatoes to do the school, which, considering that the price last winter was between $60.00 and $80.00
Per ton, certainly went far to offset the increasing costs of operation of the school owing to constantly rising prices. However, we still had the handicap of poor farming methods, in both machinery and personal. Recently, by the sale of a right-of-way through the Church lands, conveying water power to a new pulp mill that is being built, the school came into possession of a sum of cash, the opportunity occurring at the same time to purchase a Farm-all tractor, with tandem disk, power mower, plow, spring-tooth cultivator and harrows and a farm trailer, all in almost new condition. I have also rented a number of small pieces of land, about 20 acres in all, such as constitute the majority of small farms in this valley, and these are in crop. These small farms can be made to produce abundantly with efficient farming methods. We are milking 11 cows with a production of over 8000 lbs of milk during the month of May.

The opportunity now arises to get rid of the two farmers, each married and occupying cottages on the school property. The whole operation, with the tractor machinery, can be undertaken by Mr. Loewen. Neither of the farmers employed could by any means be termed instructors, nor had they any facility in handling boys. Mr. Loewen can instruct them in tractor operation and in small farming methods, such as they can engage in on many of the reserves. Not all the parents of our pupils are fishermen. At first Mr. Loewen offered to combine the manual training work with the farming operations, but this I would consider detrimental to both operations, so I wish to employ another manual instructor, who can be assisted and supervised by Mr. Loewen. Mr. Loewen has lately undertaken the building of small boats, the first of which, 20 feet long, he has almost completed. He will continue this in his spare time. If, and when he marries, he can occupy one of the farmers' cottages.

I think not, I think it necessary to increase the vocational training grant under these circumstances. This may be rather surprising to you after your very kind offer, but I have another matter that is bothering me much more than that of the vocational instructor. It is the matter of teachers' salaries.

I note in Major Mackey's evidence before the Joint Committee that he made the statement that only 24 Indian children attended High School. I presume that he meant that these 24 attended Public High School although it is not clear that this was understood by the Committee. I see by the Schedule attached to minutes 5, where Major Mackey made this statement, that, under the column "Grade 9", which is junior High School, and which might even include grades above 9, for the returns do not provide for the notation of grades higher than nine, there are 56 High School students in the Residential Schools and 15 in the day schools. There are 18 in the Residential Schools of B.C., of which the Alberni School had 8 last term. Next term, allowing for discharges, we will have 14, 1 in grade 11, 5 in grade 10, 8 in grade 9.
The Committee also seems to have been given the impression that the pupils get little, or no, encouragement from the parents to take higher education, or to make use of it when it is taken. That is definitely not so among our pupils and parents. I have had letters from parents requesting pupil continuance in High School, and the pupils, without exception, wish to continue. Most of them have an object in view, some nursing, some business course, some teaching and some technical work. Their outlook, and the support given them by the parents, is most encouraging.

Now as to the teachers. I have one unqualified, but very good teacher taking grades one and two, a class of 65, on half-day system, of course. One University Graduate teacher taking grades 3 and 4 (a poor teacher, too long in an Indian day school) with a class of 78, on half-day. One returned air-force man teaching Grades 5 and 6, with a class of 47, on half-day, and one teacher teaching grades 7, 8, 9 and 10, a class of 36, with grades 7 and 8 half-day and grades 9 and 10 full day. The teachers up to grade 6 are being paid $60.00 per month, with board and room, estimated in B.C. at $40.00, amounting to $1000.00 for the two months. One is unqualified, one qualified in B.C. and one qualified in Saskatchewan. The minimum teachers salary for these teachers would be between $1200.00 and $1500.00 at the present B.C. scale. Two of these teachers are leaving, the poor one with the B.C. qualifications wishing to remain. I doubt if she could retain a position in the public schools.

I have resorted to the scheme, since coming here, of getting teachers from the prairies, where the teaching salaries have been lower, and where B.C. has provided an attraction. Naturally, their term is only of one year, or less, until something better opens for them in B.C. By this means I have kept on until now, with excellent success, especially as regards the teacher in the senior grades, but now salaries on the prairies are better and that source will not be so productive of teachers for us.

I have left the matter of the senior teacher until the last. The man I have had this term came from Saskatchewan and has been exceptionally good. The grade 10 pupil averaged 75% in June Exams. Grade 9 averaged 76.0%, Grade 8 averaged 75%, Grade 7 averaged 67%. This man was not a High School teacher and had to work almost night and day to get the results he did... from pupils who had only had the benefit of previous half-day tuition, up to grade 6. His salary was $60.00 with board and room, an equivalent of $1100.00 for the 10 months. The minimum salary for an elementary school teacher in B.C. with the five years teaching experience this man had is $1550.00. He is not remaining. He is going back to Saskatchewan for further study.
As you know, what is called the Cameron system of enlarged and well organized school districts, directly under the Department of Education, is now operative in B.C. Teachers are scarce. If we are to get qualified teachers at all, they will be the rejects of the Public Schools, and these are not good enough to maintain the standard we have set in this school and a standard that the Indian parents now expect from us. Even if we had sufficient finances to compete with the Public School system, there are still disadvantages to overcome. The Indian School teacher is handicapped by the loss of all recognition by the Provincial Department of Education. Supernumerary is forfeited and Inspector's reports have no value in establishing seniority.... and the provincial scale of salaries is graduated by seniority, by the number of years engaged in teaching. However, we are prepared to compete with this handicap, providing we can offer equivalent salaries.

It seems almost beyond question that the Joint Committee will do something to remedy this matter; but the ramifications of the whole Indian problem which this Committee are so extensive that I cannot see any findings being brought down, or remedial measures applied, for at least two years. In the meantime what are we going to do? It seems a shame to build up a fair academic status, as compared to Public School standards, and then see it deteriorate because of lack of teachers of ability.

I am not at this time suggesting a greater number of teachers, although certainly the Committee will amend a situation where four teachers are teaching 230 children. I am content to continue with this handicap until the whole system is changed. But this matter of teachers' salaries is one of immediate urgency in B.C. I am sure that other schools (Indian) who must draw their teaching staff from the Provincial teaching profession, are in much the same position. It does not seem to me to be competent to expect the Churches to make up the deficiency and subsidize Indian education, nor do the Churches appear willing to do this further than is now done in some schools.

Can anything be done about it? The situation is entirely due to the advance in salaries in the teaching profession, perhaps also in some measure to the greatly increased consciousness of the Indian parent in adequate education, and also to the scarcity of teachers. It cannot be laid to inefficient administration of Indian School finances.

I regret having to go into so much detail to explain the situation, which, I think, is possibly more acute under the B.C. educational conditions than elsewhere. I trust that I have not imposed too great a burden on your time and patience. I would be glad, however, to know just what is the Department's reaction to this condition.

Yours very sincerely,

I note your remarks with reference to Mr. Loewen. I would be interested in knowing what additional salary he has requested. We may be able to assist you in providing part, at least, of the increase, as it would be preferable to retain his services, if at all possible.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. A. H. Caldwell,

Dear Mr. Caldwell:

We received the February report of the manual training work at the Alberni School, but we have not yet received the report for the months of March and April. These should be forwarded as soon as possible.

I would also appreciate it if you would let me know the qualifications of the instructor, Mr. Loewen and the qualifications of the assistant instructor, Mr. Strand.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Vancouver, B.C., August 20, 1947.

Re: Alberni Indian Res. School

It is recommended that authority be granted for the purchase of only those items checked in red on the attached Requisition.

It is felt that the teaching of metal work should be left until the woodwork shop is equipped and consequently the purchase of tools for the proposed metal work course is not recommended. The pupils at this School will find the woodwork of greater use. Dear Mr. Doucet,

I am enclosing the form of application for manual training instructor, completed. May I say that Mr. Stanton is a very satisfactory instructor. He was engaged after several men had been tried. While not a technical school trainee, he has had the practical experience, has the faculty of teaching, and the application of the basic course work to the construction of useful articles.

His classes now are installing a system of lockers in the school...... for which, I may say, we were required to purchase the material out of school funds.

I hope we may be able to keep Mr. Stanton. It is practically impossible to get a professionally trained man in B.C. They are in great demand in the schools.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum -

Mr. A. J. Doucet

I have reviewed the requisition for leathercraft supplies submitted by the Principal of the Alberni Residential School through the Indian Commissioner for B.C.

As no unit prices have been indicated which might be compared with other known quotations, it is difficult to determine whether the amount of $225 may be considered reasonable for the quantity of supplies listed.

As far as the quantities of tools desired are concerned, the several estimates appear quite reasonable. However, with no particulars as to the type of program being organized at Alberni, it is difficult to offer an opinion as to whether the quantity of expendable materials is reasonable or not. The total suggested appears to be large for a group just commencing its first efforts. e.g. 288 key cases seems to be a lot for a start.

The major item might well prove to be the type of tooling leather ordered. It is not clear whether the first twelve pieces are for full sides (averaging 18 to 20 feet each) or for the narrower, belly leather strips (averaging 3½ to 4 feet each). If for full sides, the estimate of $225 would be low, while if for belly leather, the estimate might be an outside figure and including all other items listed.

As in the former case I reviewed (Eskasoni) I feel some effort should be made by such groups to make their own leather lacing, since the purchasing of leather lacing can become quite an expensive matter.

Had we more details as to the type of program being planned and more exact descriptions of the quality of leather being ordered, we could come much closer to appraising this particular requisition.

In any case, the results of the program at the Alberni Residential School will be determined ultimately only by the qualifications of the instructor in leathercraft at Alberni. The amount of supplies asked for could be made to work out reasonably, or expensively - according to the ability of the instructor to make best use of materials desired.

Deane H Russell

I refer to Mr. Doucet's letter of December 15th concerning the requisition for handicraft supplies from the above mentioned school.

Attached are letters from the Principal covering the points raised in Mr. Doucet's letter.

I might add that Inspector Davey has not made a survey of the needs of this school in this kind of work.
