UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA

ALBERNI, B.C.

Dec. 31st 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
VANCOUVER, B.C. Re. Handicraft Supplies.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

I have yours of Dec. 22nd re the requisition for Handicraft supplies. This has been replied to in the enclosed letter by Mr. Maize, who is in charge of class-room and extra curricular activities.

I note that Mr. Maize states that the teachers interesting themselves in this work are not technically trained. While this is so, these teachers have been taking this work for the past year and some of them have been purchasing their own materials from the Bedford Fine Leathers Co., Vancouver. This has been, of course, for their own use.

The teachers taking this work are Mr. Maize, Miss Bone, Miss Kennedy, Miss Zehner and Mr. Avery.

Miss Zehner takes three periods weekly with her special class. Mr. Maize takes four hours weekly in evening work with the Tuxis Group and the Girls' Hobby Group. Mr. Avery takes two hours evening work weekly with the Boys' Hobby Group. Miss Bone and Miss Kennedy take two hours weekly evening work with the Canadian Girls in Training Group.

I may say that this programme is arranged to keep the pupils occupationally busy in the evenings and is made necessary owing to the lack of indoor recreational facilities at this school.

While we have not as yet disposed of any of the work of the pupils, there have been many requests for purchase of leather work, such as slippers, that we have had on exhibition.

I feel that Department supply of this material, or as much as the Department is disposed to supply, isn't warranted when the teachers are willing to put their time into the use of it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Mr. Caldwell:

In reply to your letter dated Dec. 22nd regarding our recent requisition for handicraft supplies dated October 4th.

Since the beginning of the term we have started a Practical Arts classroom for backward pupils where they receive instructions in the basic subjects and a good deal of handiwork. This room is made up of 20 pupils all engaged in leather work and we plan on starting shell work. The teacher is not a qualified handicraft instructor but is interested in the work and spends a good deal of time preparing her lessons, in said work.

In the senior class rooms grades six and seven receive practical art instruction one period a week in leather work.

The Grades 5,9,10, and 11 pupils have a hobby class each Tuesday evening. Leather work is again emphasized with shell work also planned for them.

Our C.G.I.T., Tuxis and Trail Ranger groups also meet once a week with leather work being emphasized. We would like to introduce shell work here too.

Our supplies up to last September kept us going until the end of October. Since then we have been finishing off projects as much as possible.

Our instructors have not taken courses in handicraft work but are keenly interested and spend a lot of time working up projects.

The numbers of boys and girls involved in the various groups are as follows:

|                | Girls | Boys |
|----------------|-------|------|
| Practical Arts room | 8     | 12   |
| Senior Classroom Gr. 6 | 16    | 7    |
| Gr. 7           | 18    | 11   |
| Hobby class Gr. 5,9,10,11 | 8     | 7    |
| C.G.I.T.        | 42    |      |
| Tuxis           |       | 25   |
| Trail Rangers   |       | 25   |
| Sub. Total      | 92 girls | 87 boys |
| Total           | 179 Pupils |

Last year we had C.G.I.T. and Tuxis doing all the handicraft work and their numbers are much the same this year thus there would be an increase of 112 pupils doing handicraft work this term.

The reason for larger amounts of some materials was to increase our production of finished articles for sale purposes under the auspices of the various groups and thus make up a fund with which to purchase our own supplies.

The requisition for $225 worth of tools and material for leatherwork at the Alberni Indian Residential School has been considered.

Tools have been purchased for this school during the past few years. We have no indication as to whether these tools are still on hand or if not what has happened to them.

May we presume that there is an increase in the number of pupils taking this course. How much time during the week is allotted to this work? Apparently the boys and the girls are enrolled in the leather course.

Thonging may become an expensive item in leatherwork unless it is made by the pupils themselves.

Has a survey been made by Inspector Davey of the needs of the school in this kind of work; of the number of pupils participating and of the future utility of this training?

Is the present Instructor sufficiently qualified to teach this subject efficiently?

The above information will allow us to consider these questions and enable us to reach a decision.

ALBERNI, B.C.

Re: Manual Training Grant.

Dear Mr. Carrard,

Through frequent staff changes in that Department and with new assistance in the office, the matter of manual returns and application for Department grant has been overlooked for some six months.

The last cheque we received was for June 1948 received in August.

I had engaged William Morgan as Instructor in July, but found him inefficient in that position and transferred him to boys supervision in September. Mr. A.E.V. Eastwood had the position during September and October. He was a good instructor but left at the beginning of November on account of his wife's nervous sickness. His wife was also on the staff. Since then I have had Ainslie L. Avery from the University of Saskatoon, who has been satisfactory, although not of course a qualified Technical Instructor.

The returns will, in future be made monthly, as we have got back to routine again.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Re: Manual Training Salary Grant.

Dear Mr. Carrard,

It was with some surprise that I received your advice that the Department, in a letter from Mr. Phelin, had refused to sanction the salary grant for the Manual Training Instructor for the months of July and August, on the grounds that payment for these months was "not customary".

During my term at this school the Manual Instructor has always been engaged on a twelve month salary basis. The salary being paid is $100.00 per month, with board, room and laundry. The Instructor is permitted two weeks holiday with paid salary, if his service has been of the full duration of the term.

We have had perhaps more turn-over of personnel in this position than any other in the school, for the simple reason that the salary is not sufficient for a fully competent practical man and in several instances other employment has been offered them at a salary that we cannot afford to pay. The basic salary of a Technical Arts Instructor in B.C. is around $200.00 per year of ten months. Qualified men are almost impossible to obtain as instanced by the fact that the Public High School has been unable to engage one this term.

However, the Manual Training Instructor's duties in this school are not confined to class-room teaching. All the maintenance labour is done by the Instructor and the Engineer. The months of July and August are employed by the Manual Instructor in painting mainly. In the last five years I would say that the labour thus employed, if it had been done by the Department on contract with Union Tradesmen, would amount to some thousands of dollars.

The last Instructor, Mr. Cameron, left in August to take a position with the Department of Forestry of the Province. The present incumbent, Mr. Winston Morris, has been here since the latter part of August, and his education and teaching ability seem to be of a high standard. His engagement will, of course,
Mr. Garrard 2,

be subject to the approval of his ability by Mr. Davey at his school inspection in November.

May I request, in view of these facts, that the decision of the Department be reconsidered and that the grant be continued for the full twelve months as customary.

Yours very truly,

Mr. N.W. Garrard,
Indian Superintendent,
PORT ALBERNI, B.C.

Dear Mr. Garrard,

I am in receipt of your letter of Nov. 28th advising that, as a result of my letter to you of Oct. 24th, protesting against the withholding of the manual grant for the months of July and August, the grant has been continued for the full twelve months at $100.00 per month.

I wish to thank the Department for their reconsideration of this matter. I was under the impression that the facts were not fully before them and that it only required the explanation of the terms of engagement, and the amount of additional labour undertaken by the Manual Instructor, with the consequent great saving in labour maintenance costs to the Department.

However, the grant has now been reduced from the former $125.00 per month for 12 months to $100.00. I feel that this is either an error or a misconception, caused by my mention in the letter of Oct. 24th of the salary of the Instructor as being $100.00 per month plus board, room and laundry. Our estimate of the cost of this accommodation is $40.00 per month, which is considered low for B.C. Therefore the school is expending $140.00 for the Department grant of $125.00 per month.

I may say that the auditor's report covering the 15 months up to the end of August 1949 shows a yearly expenditure of $300.00 per capita, with a Government revenue of $274.00, making a deficit of $26.00 per capita per year. We have been carrying on at this school by virtue of a Bank overdraft, with the expectation that the excessive cost of living may come down and the school operate within the present income. The tendency, however, is still for the cost of living to increase rather than decrease. The burden of finance continues to be the greatest concern of the Principal, a burden, which, I say advisedly, it would seem to be impossible to carry much longer. The Department must be aware of these conditions and I cannot think that they would seek to add to the burden by a reduction of $25.00 a month in the Manual Grant.

One alternative to maintaining the present operational cost is to reduce the salaries of all staff members. Obviously this would result in the engagement of incompetent staff and a breakdown in behaviour would follow. Another alternative is to reduce the diet, resulting in dissatisfied pupils and antagonistic parents, apart from impairment of pupil health. Either, or both, these measures would immediately bring discredit on the school and on the Government, and would, for the sake of economy beyond the point of necessity, defeat the whole purpose for which this school is kept in operation.

I have endeavoured, beyond the limits of my resources, to co-operate with the Department in maintaining the highest possible standard in every department connected with the school. I might instance just one particular case. In co-operation with the Nutrition Division of the Department of Health, in the interests of their research project, we have, at the Division's request, increased our pupil milk consumption, since last September, to an amount aggregating $3741.00 per year, about double our former expense for this item. Although a recompense has
been suggested by the Nutrition Division authority to offset the increased school expense occasioned by our co-operation in their project, no such recompense has been forthcoming.

Can the Department advise me just how I am to maintain this set standard, not only with inadequate current funds, but with the added handicap of reduced grants such as the Manual grant in question? I must conclude that this reduction has been occasioned, as I have said, by an error of conception. May I be assured, therefore, that the Manual Grant will remain as formerly?

I am enclosing an application form from a Manual Training Instructor, Mr. Paul Pollock, recently engaged. The former incumbent was discharged by me for incompetence and staff incompatibility. The new man gives promise of being a competent and efficient staff member. The change in this position has not affected in any way the continuity of the manual training classes.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School

We received Mr. Caldwell's letter of March 6th addressed to you in connection with the payments made towards the salary of the manual training teacher at the Alberni School.

It is our intention to allow a grant of $125.00 a month effective from the date on which Mr. Pollock began duties as manual training instructor. PORT ALBERNI, B.C.

Dear Mr. Garrard,

Herewith manual return and voucher for the month of March.

I do not appear to have received a cheque for the manual grant for the month of December 1949.

On Dec. 12th, I received a cheque for $500.00, being for the five months, June to Oct. inclusive at $100.00 per month. Correspondence with the Department reestablished the grant at $125.00 per month as formerly. On Jan. 14th 1950 I received the cheque for November ($125.00). On March 8th, I received cheque for $125.00, being noted as the arrears from June to October, as above. Also on this date I received cheque for $125.00 for the month of January 1950. February has not yet been received.

Now due, including March, is $375.00, grant for the months of December 1949, and Feb. and March 1950.

Will you please request the Department to check and confirm this?

Thanking you,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re Alberni Indian Residential School.

I have to refer to your letter dated October 17th, your file 159-1-12, authorizing the purchase of linoleum for the Assembly Hall at the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Approximately 133 square yards of linoleum are required and the quotations, including cost of labor, received are as follows:

Carter's Hardware, Alberni, B.C. ................. $270.00
A. McDonald & Sons, Port Alberni, B.C. .......... 308.25
J.H. Good & Co. Ltd., Port Alberni, B.C. ......... 375.00

In referring to the tenders submitted by Carter's Hardware, Principal Scott comments as follows:

"I do not know what plans Carter's Hardware may have for laying this linoleum. They did not do a very good job on a small piece which they laid in our kitchen. They may, however, be making special arrangements if they were awarded this contract. A. McDonald & Sons however, have a fully qualified linoleum layer. I have given Carter's Hardware most of our month to month purchases which amount to considerable, and I really feel that A. McDonald & Sons would give us a satisfactory job."

As A. McDonald & Sons have a qualified man for such work, whose services would be available to the school when required, I feel that it would be safer to place the order with this firm.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
The Secretary

November 14, 1940.

I have no information as to what firms at Alberni and Port Alberni are on the approved list and would, therefore, appreciate your instructions as to the placing of the order.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Dear Sir:

Your File 159-1-12.

I have received your letter of October 22nd regarding the new ironer at the Alberni Indian Residential School which was damaged while being moved into the school.

In this connection, I beg to advise that Mr. Arnall, Engineer, Dominion Department of Public Works, examined this machine during a recent inspection of the machinery, boilers and equipment at the school, and reported in part as follows:

"The ironer is badly damaged. Some parts are broken."

In view of this, I consider that my recommendation of October 4th to the Department to the effect that the Company be required to remove the damaged machine and install a complete new ironer in the school be approved.

Accounts for this machinery have not been received at this office to date but when and if they are submitted here I could not, under existing circumstances, pass same for payment.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Alberni, November 9th, 1940.

Major D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major Mackay:

I am having to buy straw at $16 a ton and have ample supply in the old barn at Coqualeetza. However, it is only worth about $3.50 a ton in the barn so you can see I cannot sell over there and buy here to any advantage. The same is true of hay. Hay is worth $23 a ton over here, but there is practically no sale for it at Sardis even at $10 a ton. There may be some hay moving later on, but the hay crop was one of the best we have ever had over there.

It costs $2.50 a ton to bale hay and $2.75 a ton to bale the straw. In addition there would be the labor of five men to assist with the baling. I am informed that it takes eight hours to bale 20 tons, which would make a car load. If the Department would be good enough to pay the freight charges inclusive of cartage both at Sardis and Alberni, I would pay the baling and labor costs for one car load of straw and one car load of hay. This would put me through for this school year, and I would undertake to provide after that wholly at school expense. The freight charges for hay and straw are approximately .38¢ per hundredweight from Sardis to Alberni in car load lots, with a minimum of 22,000 lbs. this would mean a freight charge of approximately $83.60. As the car load of vegetables was loaded in about eight hours, I am sure this hay and straw would be loaded in less time, so that an estimate of $15 at Sardis and $20 at Alberni, where the haul is somewhat longer, would cover the cartage on each car.
Major D.M. MacKay

November 9, 1940.

The baling and labor costs would be $60 on hay and $65 on straw on 20 tons, which is about all you can get in a car.

I feel that seeing we had all this fodder ready for use during the winter, and that we have been moved over here in co-operation with the Department, that to some extent the Department should share in the extra costs involved. At the same time, I appreciate more than I can tell you, the generous treatment that we have received up to now. I would be glad if you felt you could recommend this final expenditure for moving charges, to the Department.

Yours sincerely,

R.C. Scott

Re: 16 mm. Sound Projector

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Conditions in this new school, I find are somewhat different to what they were at Sardis. We are more cut off from the outside than we were there and closer to the Reserves. This creates problems that are somewhat difficult and causes a greater need for improving our equipment to the place where it will meet the need of the children in as great a measure as possible.

Not only do the children, from the West Coast especially, lack in general knowledge of and appreciation of the world outside, but because of what amounts almost to suspicion on the part of parents as to what is going on in the school, I feel that we ought to be able to help these children and at the same time show the parents in a way that they will understand, something of the real effort that is being made by the Department, to meet the needs of their children.

I find there is a disposition on the part of some staff members to assist in securing a Sound Projector for the school. Being isolated as we are, I am sure the Indians on the Reserve close at hand would help either directly or indirectly if allowed to attend a showing of the films. In doing this I would of course be careful not to incur any criticism on the part of Moving Picture theatres, and I do not see that there would be any real danger of the same.

There is a Filmo Sound Machine, 138-R-Bell & Howell's, with a 12" speaker. It has a 750 Watt Lamp and guaranteed two serviceings for the first year, the same as a new machine. It has been used simply as a Demonstration machine and is the same kind as has been installed in various military and air camps. For instance the one at Aliford Bay in the Queen Charlotte Islands is exactly the same and cost $576.00 new. The machine I have referred to can be had for $350.00.

I feel that it is an excellent buy and if the Department could assist, we may be able to handle it for instance if a grant of $125 could be made for a down payment. I feel sure that we could get the balance in the ways just mentioned above.

While we can get along with the small Silent Projector which we have, it does not afford access to anything like the same number of films, educational and otherwise, as can be found in the Sound Libraries.
Mr. R.A. Hoey,

November 6th, 1940

I realize that the Department is spending a lot of money on this school, and I shall abide by your decision, whatever it may be, but as stated above, I feel it would be a real advantage. I was not able to get anything from the Company by turning in our present small machine.

Thanking you for your interest and assistance

I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Major MacKay:

In reading the report of Indian Agent Ashbridge for the month ended October 31 I note that he mentions the fact that the enamel cups and dishes at the Alberni Residential School are badly chipped and difficult to sterilize.

You will recall that on the occasion of my last visit to British Columbia we visited a boys' school operated near Duncan, B.C., and at that time we saw a very fine class of tableware which had been manufactured in England. Is it possible to obtain this type of equipment in British Columbia? If so, you might make inquiries regarding what it would cost to equip the children's dining room in the Alberni School.

Dear Sir:

Memorandum:

Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Please find herewith a copy of a letter received today from the Beaver Laundry Machinery Company Limited, Toronto, in answer to my letter of the 21st ultimo regarding the unsatisfactory condition of the Ironer supplied by this firm on Purchase Order No. 3105. You will note that the company proposes to supply two new frames for the ironer, as an alternative to installing a complete new ironer.

I should be pleased to have your comment and advice regarding the company's proposal. We will defer replying until you have had an opportunity of securing Commissioner MacKay's advice in the matter. If he is satisfied with the alternative now suggested by the company we have no objection to sanctioning the new arrangement. However, if Commissioner MacKay is not satisfied with the company's suggested alternative of supplying new frames instead of a complete new ironer, it is not our intention to retract from the position indicated in the second paragraph of my letter of the 21st ultimo to the Beaver Laundry Machinery Company, in which we stated that a complete new 66" Ironer must be furnished and that payment of their account would be deferred until this was supplied and installed to the complete satisfaction of Commissioner MacKay.

[Signature]

Departmental Purchasing Agent.
THE BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY CO., LIMITED

Toronto, December 11, 1940.

The Purchasing Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs,-

Re: Your File 34590-15-20-1

Please accept our thanks for yours of November 21st, copy of which was forwarded to us by our Mr. LeCours of Ottawa, and wish to advise that we immediately wrote our Vancouver Office regarding the Alberni Indian Residential School. On the last report we had from our Mr. Fraser at Vancouver he reported that the machines were all working satisfactorily, and can assure you that we certainly regret the breakage of the frame on the Flatwork Ironer. We note that Mr. Fraser has had the breakage welded on these frames, and in that way the School is not held up for their laundry work.

We note contents of your letter in which you wish us to supply you with a complete new Ironer on this contract. We do not think this would be necessary as it is only the frames of the Ironer that are broken, and all that would have to be replaced is the frames. We can assure you that when this Ironer left our factory, it was in first class condition, and that the breakage occurred due to getting same into the School at Port Alberni, B.C.

We believe that the department will be fair enough to us in this matter, and we will ship them two new frames for this machine, and same will be installed on said Ironer at Alberni Indian Residential School, Port Alberni, B.C., and we trust that as soon as this replacement is made it will be satisfactory to the department.

Yours very truly,

THE BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY COMPANY LIMITED,

(sgd) C.D.Edgar,
Vice-President and Sales Director.

Dear Mr Ashbridge:

Re Materials for lockers and cupboards in Boys and Girls' Dormitories.

I beg to enclose herewith estimates for materials for the above purposes. Under date of November 26th last, Major MacKay wrote me asking me to send you such information in order that prices might be secured from local firms. I enclose a copy of his letter.

I would like to draw the attention of the Commissioner to the fact that this amount is much less than the amount which I suggested to him in the conversation referred to above. In fact it will be only about one half the cost.

This is due to my having yielded, at last, to the repeated requests of the supervisors on Boys' and Girls' sides, for some accommodation for storing bed linen etc. in the dormitories. This equipment, sheets, pillow cases etc. was simply left piled on the floors in the dormitories and was not only unsightly but unsanitary also.

Consequently, I told our Board that he might order sufficient lumber for lockers in each dormitory. I had in mind only a cupboard to cover each of two windows, just over the radiators. This would accomplish two things, namely, provide a covering for the windows which are now left one whether on Boys' and Girls' sides, and at the same time afford a place for storing bedding which would be always dry.

Owing to a misunderstanding of the meaning of the term "Cupboards", Mr Huddleston ordered enough lumber to build continuous cupboards between these windows as well as to merely cover them. Thus we have now on hand sufficient lumber to build all the cupboards on the Girls' side, and need only that for the Boys' side as set forth in the enclosed estimates.

While I realize that this amount ought rightly to have come before the Department before being purchased, still, it was the result of a misunderstanding between me and Mr Huddleston. I proposed to buy only sufficient material for linen cupboards, and would have been quite prepared to have paid for it out of School funds. As it has turned out, I am now faced with payment of a bill for a much larger amount, as shown on the enclosed statements from Bloedel Stewart and Welch.

Consequently, I would be glad if you would forward this account to the Department at the same time as you send in the estimates for materials to complete the cupboards.

I might point out that the estimate for hardware is for the complete sets of cupboards on both Boys' and Girls' sides as none was purchased previously.

I may say that I have asked for prices from both the large lumber firms, Bloedel Stewart and Welch, and the Alberni-Pacific Co., but have not found any difference in their prices. Hence I did not hesitate to give the above partial order to the former.

If the remaining materials were ordered from the A.P.L.Co., it would give them each an equal amount of account.

I enclose herewith one copy of the Bloedel Stewart and Welch invoice to be forwarded to the Department. I shall hold the other three copies until it is known whether the Department will be good enough to authorize its use.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Major MacKay:

Re Lino in School Basement Playrooms Etc.

I have already reported that the lino in the boys' and girls' playrooms is overlapping in places and in danger of being broken and destroyed. I also said that I intended having a local man in, a competent linoleum layer, to do what could be done to save this expensive equipment.

He came in yesterday and cut the edges of some of the strips thus allowing them to expand in the hope that bulges etc would straighten out.

He informs me, however, that all this lino on basement floors will, in the end, and likely by the end of this school year, become rotten and spoiled owing to dampness coming through the cement floors upon which it is laid. He turned up the edges of the lino in several places and it showed distinct signs of mould and it smelled badly.

He recommends that it be taken up and the lino stood on end in rolls and the floors be washed well, and allowed to dry. The only thing is that it will take some months for this to be accomplished.

Even though it will be decidedly inconvenient, and will not help to make the boys happy to have to live in a playroom with rough cement floor after having the linoleum, I feel the steps recommended ought to be taken.

I am not asking that you authorize financial outlay in this regard at the moment. I am paying for this man's work out of school funds as it is "repair" work, but I would appreciate your advice on following the suggestion given by the above man. Further, if the floors are allowed to dry out, perhaps some top dressing could be used on them which could be put on ourselves which would lessen, if not remove entirely, the danger of dampness from the floors attacking the lino. As this should have been done in the first place, I feel it might be a fair charge on the Department.
As I have already said, I am not writing for the purpose of asking financial assistance in this matter, but on the other hand, feel that any step as suggested is on such a scale, and of such importance, and is a right-about-face on the action of the Department in putting this lino down on floors of cement below ground level, that I feel I ought to have your consent or otherwise before taking this action.

The only alternative is to allow the flooring to remain as it is, cut the edges from time to time to keep it as flat as possible, and run the risk of having it rot, and then of having a bigger job on our hands in the end to recondition the floors.

If you think it best to allow the lino to remain as at present, then I shall do so, but it seems the part of wisdom to do anything we can to lengthen its life and justify the outlay already taken in putting it down.

Awaiting your reply, I am,

Yours sincerely,

"R.C. Scott"

PRINCIPAL.
Residential School, Alberni

Re Linoleum to Floors in Basement

Play room corridors, dining rooms in basement below grade, concrete base, are covered with linoleum.

The linoleum is apparently cemented to concrete floor, which has not been previously damp-proofed.

The linoleum cement, through dampness in concrete slab, has failed and the linoleum in many places is loose, badly blistered and puckered. The linoleum cement is wet, gives off an objectionable odour and is fast deteriorating, and is a hazard to pupils.

We recommend that all linoleum in basement should be lifted and any cement adhering either to the floor or linoleum should be removed and the concrete floor thoroughly cleaned and dried. Tremco 122 Linoleum Damp-proofing should be applied and lino-felt underlayment installed, and the linoleum cement in waterproof cement.

All linoleum which has not been previously waxed, as in play rooms, corridors and students' lunch room, should be given two coats Tremco Penetren.

Having regard to conditions, this work should be done during summer months.
Alberni Day School, Alberni

Sir Flooring

The flooring in this building is showing fast deterioration, and it appears as if the flooring at installation was treated with linseed oil only.

In corridors, cloak rooms and aisles between desks, and at wall surrounds in front of blackboards, dirt is settling and penetrating into flooring, greatly reducing its life and leaving the floors in a dirty condition, almost impossible to clean.

Due to the present condition and appearance of these floors we strongly recommend that the floors and corridors should be sanded, removing stain now in floors together with existing oil finish, and then treated with an application of Tremco Paste Filler and two coats Tremco Penetron Floor Finish.

We were advised by Rev. Scott that there is a quantity of linoleum on hand sufficient to fit on the stair treads leading from main entrance to landing, also to landing areas separating class rooms, and we would recommend that this be laid in these areas. This would reduce noise from pupils during class changes, the linoleum to be protected on stair treads by metal nosings of approved design and securely fastened.

Due to the condition of the floor we would respectfully suggest that the sanding, filling and application of Penetron, and application of linoleum on stair treads, etc., as above mentioned, should be done by us to insure a first class job. The total cost of the above work would be two hundred and eighty-five dollars ($285.00).

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

Re: Purchase order No. 4702
Linoleum for Alberni School

In connection with our requisition for this linoleum dated November 19, 1940, I enclosed a copy of a letter received from Indian Commissioner MacKay.

The firm of H.C. Carter was awarded the business and Indian Commissioner MacKay, in a letter dated the 11th instant, writes as follows:

"I enclose herewith a letter received from the Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School relative to linoleum supplied by H.C. Carter of Alberni for the Assembly Hall of this institution.

"Under separate cover I am forwarding a sample of the linoleum laid by the contractors in this Hall and another of that supplied by Mr. Carter, from which it would appear that he has not supplied the material called for by the Department, with the result that the Hall is now covered by two lots of linoleum of entirely different thicknesses. This will cause breaking down of the edges of the thick material and necessitate an early replacement of that supplied by Mr. Carter.

"In this connection, I would refer to Mr. Purchasing Agent Bailey's letter of November 21, 1940, file 36,517-15-28."
"Mr. Commissioner MacKay will arrive in Ottawa in the near future when the matter could no doubt be discussed with him if the Department so desires."

The account covering the cost of the linoleum has not yet been received. I should appreciate your advising me what action can be taken in view of the contents of Commissioner MacKay's letter.

The sample of linoleum is attached.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

April 15th, 1941

Mr. P.W. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent,
Fort Alberni, B.C.

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

This is to advise you that the two ironer ends, No. 2842-R and 2842-L from the Beaver Laundry Company, have been received and are now at the school.

These ends are in blank, only the main shafting holes being drilled. It will be necessary to take the mangle apart and set it on the new ends to mark them for fitting. Seventeen holes will have to be drilled on the right end and thirteen holes on the left end. These holes will have to be tapped as well to take the brackets and fittings. As the machine will have to be taken down, levelled and squared for setting up before these holes can be marked and drilled, it will take at least two days work. The job ought to be done at a time when it would inconvenience laundry work as little as possible. As some of these holes are from 5/8" to 11/16" it will take a heavy electric drill and we have not got such equipment, although it might be possible to rent it.

I would be glad if you would advise Major MacKay that these ends have come, and I shall await further instructions.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM

April 12, 1941.

Mr. W.W. McCutcheon

We have had considerable correspondence with the Beaver Laundry Machinery Company, Toronto, Ont., regarding the damage to an Ironer supplied and installed with other laundry equipment on Purchase Order No. 3105. As a result of this correspondence, we wrote Beaver Laundry Machinery Company Limited on the 4th January as follows:

"Reply to your letter of the 11th ultimo, regarding condition of Ironer supplied on P.O. 3105 has been deferred pending receipt of additional information from our western representatives.

"Instead of replacing the Ironer originally supplied in accordance with my letter of Oct. 10, 1940, it will be satisfactory to this Department if you will arrange as follows:

(a) Damaged frames to be replaced by new ones by your company without cost to this Department.

(b) The roller which was bent as a result of the accident to the Ironer, and had to be straightened, to be replaced by your company provided it gives any trouble within the twelve months' period covered by your guarantee against defective parts.

Kindly arrange accordingly at your earliest convenience, so that we may arrange for payment of your account."

I have been informed by Indian Affairs Branch that the damaged frames and roller have been replaced by the company. It will therefore be in order to arrange for payment of the Ironer at $896.40, Sales Tax included, f.o.b. Port Alberni, B.C.

Acting Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Dear Dr. Dorsey:

It is very essential that I have some definite information with regard to the future of the farm in order that I may make arrangements for the transfer of stock, etc. I am willing to undertake responsibility for the farm to the end of September. I would like however to submit the following facts for your consideration. As the Department may be involved in any settlement, and doubtless you would like to confer with them, I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Hoey for his information.

We have in all, thirty-three head of cattle, including ten yearlings and under, and one purchased Guernsey bull. We have also six brood sows, two of which have litters of four and they will have litters within the next two weeks. We have four work horses and one yearling gelding which we obtained from a colt. Three of these horses I purchased out of school funds, the fourth being one which came down from Dr. Haley's time, but we have two first class teams and this young yearling that can be used in about a year's time. I could not accommodate more than twenty head of cattle at Alberni and accommodation is still to be made for the hogs. The one team is plenty for that school.

I think a decision as to whether the Department wants to take over the farm should be secured, and whether they wish to continue to work it this coming Fall and Winter. The taxes are due November 2nd next, and this would mean that Coqualeetza School is liable for eleven months of the year, leaving one month to be taken care of from some other source. If the farm is left vacant it means taxes will accrue with no revenue to meet same. Betterment will at once set in and if the Department takes it over, they will be a year behind in providing dairy and farm produce for the Sanatorium. There are seven acres already ploughed which will need discing right away. There are twenty-five acres that should be ploughed as soon as possible. Added to the above reasons, so far as the Department is concerned, there is need for fresh milk and vegetables for the fifteen children that will be left here in the Preventorium.

I would respectfully submit, that to my mind it would be good business for the Department to take over the farm and maintain Mr. Carter who is really an excellent farmer, or some other such man, who would give the proper care to the stock and keep the farm in good condition and also act as caretaker for all this property until it is reconditioned and operating as a sanatorium when definite plans could be made.
Rev. George Dorsey, D.D.,

August 21, 1940

As the matter of the future oversight of the Preventorium is a pressing one, I shall write you in a day or two and send a copy of the letter which I hope to address to the Commissioner through Dr. McQuarrie.

In closing, I am going to take at least twelve head, most of the milkers, to Alberni as this will constitute one our loads. I shall also take some of the hogs. I shall leave the rest of the cattle to provide milk for the Preventorium and shall leave the horses until I hear from you. I would point out that this is the wrong time of year to sell horses.

I shall appreciate an early reply and thank you in anticipation of your consideration of this problem. With kind regards I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Pitts,

In accordance with your wishes I am submitting the following information re the organization of a band in your school.

Re Instruction:

I have written to Mr. J. Kyle of the Technical BR. of the Education Dept. to have him confirm by letter that his Dept. will arrange for an instructor to teach the boys the instruments. Once he gives his permission in writing I can arrange to have a man go out from Port Alberni, twice a week to teach them. I could arrange to go myself if no one else chooses as I have already instructed and led three Boys' Bands.

Re Instruments:

Rather than see the boys have poor instruments and, if I were to be the instructor, I would sooner see them not begin. I strongly recommend British-made instruments for, beyond a doubt, they possess better material and workmanship than the American-made. There are three British instruments that I think all good bandsmen would be ready to recommend. They are the Hawkes, the Beeson and the Boosey. The Boosey is, I think, more popular than the others and a little cheaper in Canada. It is used by most of the good bands in the British Isles. All British Instruments are hand-made. The different layers of metal are pounded together with wooden mallets and are not so apt to have small air-pockets between the layers as the machine-made instruments. Some of the American instruments look very nice but when one blows them he detects skimpy material. The firms save on material and depend on advertising to sell their goods. Some cheaper instruments have a weak alloy more nearer to copper than they should. They are more easily dented than the dearer
Mr. Pitt,

and what is worse, whenever they get warm, the keys jam, because copper has a different expansion than brass.

(ALL THE ABOVE APPLIES TO THE BRASS SECTION OF THE BAND. A SAVING WOULD BE MADE BY BUYING CANADIAN DRUMS AND FRENCH CLARINETS BECAUSE BRITISH CLARINETS ARE SKY HIGH FOR SOME UNFATHOMABLE REASON.)

French and Italian Clarinets are cheaper and considered exceptionally good.

I have tried to make inquiries from a music store in Vancouver, one in Nanaimo, and one in Victoria. The firm in Vancouver, Copeland and Euper, stated that they could equip the school with any of three makes of instruments made in British Isles and one made in Canada. I have to state that these pupils appear to be above the ordinary run of intelligence, but unless technical training can be given them during the High School training, such as instruction in repairs and operation of internal combustion engines, carpentry and navigation, I fail to see where a High School training is going to benefit them, as all classes of employment are now over stocked with white youths, and yearly becoming more so, waiting for opportunities for employment, and it is an indisputable fact that whites always get the preference in employment. Dear Miss Norris:

I am altogether at a loss to know where we are at with our Indian School management. Neither the Indian Department nor the Church seem to have any definite policy as to what is to be done in an Indian School. This has pretty well broken up our senior work and dampened our interest in it.

Last year we had five boys in Fort Alberni High School and five more in Entrance here. When I reported the work of the High School boys to the Department at the beginning of June, Mr. J.D. Sutherland, without being asked, granted permission for these boys to remain in school here as per capita pupils and to pay the High School fees ($280.00) for this year (Dept. letter June 7, 1935 No. 159-1-22). A letter from his office dated July 24th, enclosing one from Mr. Beaton dated July 17th, said that the Indian Department thought these boys should go to Coqualeetza and that he "was entirely in accord with this viewpoint."

I took the matter up with Principal Scott of Coqualeetza. His reply was indefinite, saying that they had more boys now than they could rightly accommodate but that they would be open for a few more girls. Three of the High School boys decided they would not go to Coqualeetza. I had made application for the other two to the Dept. to have them transferred to Coqualeetza as per your letter of Aug. 9th. A letter from Mr. Sutherland to the Indian Agent in reply to these applications, dated August 27th, states that "the Department does not feel that it is advisable to transfer these two pupils. It is considered that they should be discharged from the Alberni School."

I am putting the three High School boys and last year's entrance class on our discharge sheet for this quarter and am starting the other two boys who did so well at High School last year, to Fort Alberni High School until I have further instructions as to what should be done.

Another difficulty in this connection is that one of our boys in last year's entrance class made application through the Agent at Duncan, to attend Coqualeetza, and Principal Scott told him to come on to school. The Ahousant pupils have passed through here on their way to Coqualeetza. I understand there are six of them in school there now. The Indian Agent tells me that Principal Caldwell has permission for only two of them to attend.

Naturally our pupils and Indians here are asking why our pupils have not the same chance as the others.

Hoping for an early reply, I remain,

Yours obediently,

(signed) F.E. Pitts.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I have your letter of the third instant, with reference to sending pupils from the Alberni and Ahousaht Indian Residential Schools, who have passed their Entrance examinations, to the Coqualeetza Residential School, in order that they can continue their high school studies.

In this connection I would say that, last academic year, the Department allowed the advanced educational grant for five pupils of the Alberni School, who attended the Alberni District High School. When the Principal forwarded the request for payment of the grant in June, last, he was informed, should these boys wish to continue attending high school in Alberni during the present academic year, the Department would continue the grant for them. In replying, he requested that two of the boys, Eddie Clutesi and William Tatcoosh, be sent to Coqualeetza. As one of these boys is 17 and the other in his 18th year, the Department did not consider it advisable to send them to Coqualeetza. We are not aware of any reason why the boys from the Alberni School could not take high school work at the Alberni High School.

The Department doubts the wisdom of sending boys 17 and 18 years of age from the west coast, inland, to Coqualeetza. After three or four years, they would have to return to their home reserves and take up their future life work, and it is doubtful if they would then be any better prepared to make a living. It will not likely be possible, for some years, at least, for them to obtain employment in offices or in business, and their only future, therefore, is to return to their homes, where they will be handicapped by being behind the other boys in becoming established.

This applies, also, in the case of pupils from

After discussing with the Deputy Minister the matter of advanced education for the pupils from the two above named schools, it was considered advisable, if they could not arrange to attend high school locally, that they be given their discharge and take up work on their reserves leading to their future establishment.

If the Principal of the Ahousaht School has sent the boys to Coqualeetza, I cannot find that this Department gave any authority. The Principals of both schools should understand, before transferring any pupils to other residential schools, that the necessary authority of the Department should first be obtained.

I am sure that, upon consideration of the question of advanced education for Indian children of the west coast, you will agree that no great advantage could be obtained in their transfer to Coqualeetza for a three or four year period in order that they can matriculate from high school. The advanced education they would receive would not be of any great use to them in their means of obtaining their future livelihood.

Dear Major MacKay:

While at Port Alberni a few days ago, Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge mentioned the fact that there were three Indian boys, previously pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School, who during the past few years have been attending the Alberni High School. It would appear that these boys:

Willie Tatoosh
Edward Clutesi
Charlie Clutesi

were per capita-drawing pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School and that they attended Alberni High School for classes, returning to the Indian Residential School daily after school.

From time to time during the past few years I have seen reports from the Principal of the Alberni High School with regard to the progress of these pupils, and have in fact mentioned these in my own reports on the Indian Residential School.

It appears that Willie Tatoosh and Edward Clutesi are now wishing to enter the 4th and last year of the High School course, while Charlie Clutesi wishes to take the 3rd year.

I consider that these boys are too old to be received as per capita-drawing pupils of an Indian Residential School but I do not wish to place any obstacle in the way of their graduation from High School. I see no reason why these boys should not live in their homes on the Indian Reserve and attend the Alberni High School daily. I understand that they would be allowed to do this, provided the usual High School fees were paid. Owing to the exceptional nature of the case and the fact that the boys are doing so well in school, I would recommend that they be allowed to continue there for another year, and that their School fees and cost of necessary textbooks be borne by the Indian Affairs Branch.

The Principal of the Alberni High School would, no doubt, be prepared to furnish Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge with a copy of the quarterly school report in the case of each of these pupils. Such reports would no doubt be necessary should the Department wish to consider the provision of further education for the above-named pupils at the close of the present academic year in June, 1938.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Ottawa, October 15, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a request for tuition grants sufficient to enable Eddie Kluteesi and Willie Tatooch to proceed with their high school studies at the Alberni district high school.

It would appear that both these pupils have been in attendance at the high school during the last three years and have obtained very creditable marks. In view of this fact, the Department is sympathetically disposed to assist them in completing their high school studies.

I am anxious to know what arrangements can be made to have these boys continue at high school. You might let me know the approximate cost of board, tuition fees, etc., and, if these appear to you to be reasonable, I am inclined to think the boys should be permitted to take up their studies at once. You might also let us know what your opinion is with respect to Charlie Kluteesi. This boy has spent one year at high school and, according to our records, is 14 years old. It is just possible, in view of the lateness of the season, that this boy might be well advised to postpone his attendance at high school until next year.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of October 15, 1937, in connection with further High School study for Eddie Klutesi, Willie Tatoosh and Charlie Klutesi of this Agency.

Since receipt of your letter, I received authority under your letter to the Commissioner, of October 8th, file 159-1-25, for these boys to be permitted to resume their courses, and arrangements were made with the Principal of the Alberni District High School to admit them. These boys will all live at their own homes, and attend school daily at no further expense to the Department.

With regard to Charlie Klutesi, this boy is away at the fishing grounds and has not yet reported to me, but it is hoped that he may decide to postpone his attendance until next year, as you propose. This I would advise, as he is not quite up to the standard of the other two boys, and a course in marine engineering would be more suitable for him. On his return, I will talk the matter over and report further regarding him.

With respect to Eddie Klutesi and Willie Tatoosh, these boys have a splendid progress report and I am doing all I can to further their interests against the time they leave school. Unfortunately, in many cases promising pupils have fallen under the influence of the older people and leaving school and reverting to Indian habits and mode of living, and I hope of these two boys setting a new standard as an example for other pupils to try to attain.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, reporting the death of three pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School, viz., Mary Bob, Violet McKay and Bertha Fred.

In this connection I would refer you to circular letter dated April 17th, 1935, in which you were informed that, upon the death of a pupil, an enquiry should be held immediately, and forms for the purpose were sent you. This action is necessary in order to protect both the school authorities and departmental officials, and, at the same time, give the Department full information regarding the circumstances attending the death of a pupil at a residential school.

I enclose the necessary forms, which should be filled in for each pupil. These forms should be signed by the Principal and the Medical Officer who attended the pupils at the time of their death and also by you. In future, I would request that you have one of these forms prepared and forwarded as soon as possible after the death of a pupil.

Yours truly,

History of Mary Bob's Case.

Went to her parents for holidays in summer. Worked in Deep Bay Cannery part of holidays. Returned to school soon after opening. Complained of some stomach trouble in October; was in bed, temperature 102; was troubled with vomiting. I feared appendicitis and had her examined a couple of times by Dr. Thomas. Was back in class room. Was not well again about Dec. 16th. Complained of headache and vomiting, temperature about 102. Was in bed two weeks. Dr. saw her than a couple of times. She was around as usual during Christmas holidays and back in classroom till the flu started. Her symptoms same as others except that she complained of pain in stomach and side. I called Dr. Thomas at once, as I thought it might be appendicitis. After careful examination, Dr. thought it was stomach flu, but said that she had better go to the hospital. He went back to hospital, arranged for bed and I took her in car half an hour later, Jan. 24th. Died in hospital Feb. 5th. I saw her three or four times during that week, thought she was going down and wrote and phoned her parents. Owing to roads blocked with snow, was not able to get a message through till Thursday, Feb. 4th, by favour of Nanose Lumber Co. Father phoned as soon as he got the message and came by train, Thursday P.M., Mother, Friday P.M. Daughter died early Saturday morning. Mother went back on Saturday; Father took the remains Monday, home to Nanose Bay for burial.

H.E. Pitts

Indian Residential School
Rev. F. E. Pitts, B.A., Principal

History of Violet McKay's Case

Had very bad attack of measles, one of the last to take them, about June 24th; had high temperature and temperature remained up after measles disappeared, which we always considered due to T.B. tendency. She remained in bed till July 17th and went by boat to her parents at Ucluelet. Was under the doctor's care and did not return until about 10 days after the others. Was not looking well but was playful and active as ever. At times she had a vacant stare that struck us as strange and is seen only in cases of meningitis.

On Feb. 8th complained of not being well, went to bed and was given laxative and aspirin compound; following day complained of soreness of spinal column. I called Dr. Thomas at once and told him I feared meningitis. He came soon after and said he feared it was T.B. meningitis and as we had her isolated we decided to keep her until next day. She got so much worse through the night that we had to stay by her bed to keep her in and grew gradually worse toward the next night.

Had ambulance and nurse from Port Alberni to remove her to hospital, Wed. Feb. 9th. Grew gradually worse and died in hospital Sunday morning Feb. 14. I had phoned her father, Jimmy McKay at Ucluelet. He came at once and was with her a couple of days before she died.

Mystery of Bertha Fred's Case—Died Feb. 14/37

Had what the doctors called German measles in May. Was well over these and about June 10 contracted the old fashioned measles, ran a high temperature and was in bed until July 11. Went with father on boat for holidays. Returned to school Aug. 15th looking rather miserable, but picked up some in looks and strength. Had Dr. Thomas examine her a number of times. He thought there was nothing seriously wrong. We tried all fall to build her up with resting in bed in the forenoon, cod-liver oil, egg-noggs, cocomalt, etc. She seemed to be improving but flu struck our school and she was very sick with high temperature for a week. Feb. 8th we feared meningitis. After examination by Dr. Thomas we kept her at school with Violet McKay until the following day and sent her to hospital in ambulance with nurse at same time as Viålet McKay. I tried to get her father but as he was on an Island down the canal I was unable to get in touch with him until his brother went for him by gas boat on Friday. She died in hospital Sunday morning, Feb. 14th.

F. E. Pitts

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School, requesting payment of burial expenses incurred in connection with the death of a pupil.

So far as I am aware, accounts of this nature have not been submitted for payment by the Department for any Indian Residential School in this Province and I am of the opinion that it is properly a charge against the school administration. However, it would be appreciated if you would advise me in the matter.

The rest of the Reverend Scott's letter dealing with the hospitalization of this child has been discussed with Dr. McQuarrie, Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services, and it has been ascertained that the objection to the child's removal from Alberni to the Hospital mentioned is that the hospital lacks accommodation for such cases and because of the infectious nature of the disease.

Dear Mr. Dewdney:-

In reply to your note of yesterday I beg to state that the amount voted for the Industrial School at Williams Lake is $6,220; but you are in error in supposing that this amount was voted in order to obtain possession of the buildings at that place. Bishop Durien first offered to sell one of the buildings and 12 acres of land for $2,350; but he afterwards submitted an alternative proposal to maintain in the buildings at Fort William an Industrial School provided the Government would grant annually $130 per capita for the pupils educated thereat, and that provision for 50 children at the above rate were made for the first year. When the
matter was submitted to you you decided that the offer to conduct the Industrial School at $130 a head was "a reasonable one and should be entertained".

I shall write Mr. Vowell in reference to Mr. Barnard's letter to him, informing him why the present arrangement was made with the school, and that, as all the Indians, as far as the Department knows, are Catholics, no question ever arose as to the school being put under other than Catholic control.

Yours sincerely

The Hon. E. Dewdney,

In answer to the Deputy Minister's memorandum on the letter addressed by Mr. Vowell to the Department on the 16th instant, the undersigned has the honour to report that for the year 1891 there was provided in the Estimates the sum of $3,250 as a Capitation Grant for 25 pupils at the William's Lake Industrial School, at $130 each. In considering the Estimates as they were originally prepared, and in connection with a letter received from Bishop Durion, dated 18th of March 1890, in which he informed the Department that buildings for the school had already been erected; that there was plenty of good land available, with a sufficiency of implements and cattle; and that there was accommodation for 40 pupils; it was decided to utilize the sum set apart for salaries and rations as an addition to the Capitation Grant of $3,250, and thus to provide for the accommodation of 50 pupils at $60 each, and the money was voted by Parliament.

Sir,

The Father acting for me at William's Lake Industrial School during my long spell of sickness, writes me that the parents of the children and the children themselves are asking for vacation. That Mr. Macdonald, the Indian Agent, wishes him to grant the request, I mean to let the children free to go home for a month or so. Now I beg leave to present to your consideration that the agreement between the government and his Lordship was $130.00 per head per annum, no mention being made of vacation. If the government wants to give vacation to the children, it is all right, but as the government has been paying according to the number of days of attendance, in order to get the whole grant I am entitled to, I will have to count, in the report, the vacation days as full days. I am sure you will see the justice of the remarks, especially, if you take into consideration that all the servants employed for the school have their wages running on vacation or no vacation, and that I will have to pay them and board them during that time for doing nothing; to discharge them during vacation time is out of the question.

Sir;—

I beg to call your attention to the manner in which a certain department of the Indian Industrial school at Williams Lake, in the Caribou District, is carried on. I refer to the harness and saddlery department. A few weeks ago, while on a trip over the Caribou road in connection with my business at Clinton, I was informed on good authority that the settlers along the road were being supplied with harness and other leather goods manufactured at this school, and that orders for these goods are being solicited by parties connected with the school. I was also informed that the manager of the harness department undertook to engage a man to drive him through the Chilcoten country for the purpose of soliciting orders for goods manufactured at the school. I have good reason to believe this to be a fact, and if the matter is allowed to continue in this way it is impossible for any person carrying on a legitimate business in these lines to compete with such an institution as this, as they can manufacture goods at penitentiary prices; in fact I believe that their goods are made up by Indians who pay for tuition in the school, while we have to employ competent and expensive men to make up our goods. It is generally supposed that the object of this department of the school is simply to teach the Indians to make harness, saddles, chaperejos &c for their own use, and not to make up stock to sell. Whether this is a fact or not, I do not know, but I understand that it is the intention of the parties who are in charge of the school to do a considerable amount of business in lines of goods manufactured by Indian pupils, assisted by their teachers. I therefore desire to be informed whether or not the managers of this school are authorized by the Indian Department to carry on business in this way, and if so, how the profits derived therefrom are directed to be applied. I forward by today's mail copies of this letter to Mr. Mara, M.P., and to Mr. A.W. Vowell, Supt. of Indian Affairs at Victoria. Should any correspondence ensue regarding this matter, I would ask that my name be not mentioned, unless it is considered quite necessary.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication also enclosed as stated; and in answer to the divers complaints made against this Mission by Mr. O.E. Caron Gibson managing director of the Cariboo Trading Co., in his letter dated July 23rd 1900 I beg to state as follows:

The above gentleman accuses us of engaging in a regular trading business and being subsidized by the Government we should not be allowed to compete with those who receive no assistance from the Government and to prove his assertions he says:

1st That we have a large house and Blacksmith shop at 3 Mile Creek.

To this we say: We have a small shed erected thereon mentioned size 16 x 24 feet which was put up there for storing our farm products and receiving freight consigned to us from Atherton instead of having to go and get same from 1st Mile House a distance of seven miles. This is the large warehouse alluded to in the above paragraph.

We emphatically deny having a Blacksmith shop at 3 Mile Creek nor have we any interest in same. The facts are that: On the 17th day of March 1900 Mr. John Doherty secured a 30 years lease from the Oblates of Mary Immaculate who are incorporated in this Province with...
headquarters at New Westminster and owners of the St. Joseph's Mission property. Said John Doherty built a blacksmith shop on the land (5 acres) located near the mission, near our warehouses.

From the above you will at once see that Mr. Doherty is the sole owner of the Blacksmith shop and is conducting same as a private business enterprise; consequently the following assertion of Mr. Carson Gibson is wrong "that although by acting through an agent at 3 Mile Creek we may pretend to be disinterested in the Blacksmith Shop while benefitting..."

2nd - Mr. Carson Gibson says that at 3 Mile Creek hay and grain are supplied and sold through their agent at the Blacksmith Shop setting prices to an absurd figure and making a profit which they are enabled to do owing to their Government subsidy.

We are quite astonished to hear that Mr. Carson Gibson complains of our setting prices on hay and grains particularly on hay we were under the impression that it was the reverse; We never sold any hay for less than $1.50 a pound, while he sells for $1.60. A small portion of our grain was sold by Mr. Doherty at $2.50 per pound and we were and still are under the impression that we were getting the market price. I may further add that Mr. Carson Gibson was offered our grain at the same figure and refused to take it.

compel us to follow his example in this or any other matter.

I may also add that Mr. Carne Gibson, Hotel Keeper, Merchant, Farmer, Stock Raiser, and consequently a wealthy man may have known views on these questions but the poorer classes such as tenants, miners, working men etc., also have very different views on the same questions and are entitled to use the same arguments as Mr. Carne Gibson and argue that as we are being subsidized by the Government we should control the price of our products; the last named persons being the great majority and the support of our district are entitled to a hearing as well as Mr. Carne Gibson.

The mission has a farm here and has had it for the past thirty years; during that time they have worked and operated it just as they are doing today. Mr. Carne Gibson has certainly been misled for we have no Butcher shop nor will we ever have. We only sold or gave away beef in fewer cases of great necessity. Times our late school Teacher was a Presbyterian; Mr. Foster who was in our employ for three years as instructor in the harness department was also a Presbyterian.

Mr. Gibson says: "The obvious unfairness of allowing Government assistance to parties to compete in trade needs no comment. The matter was once previously attempted by those same Mission people but was quickly terminated after it had been brought to the notice of your predecessor."

To the first part of the above paragraph. They too state that the Dominion Government does not now nor it ever subsidized the mission to compete against other traders. The subsidy was given for the school and is being used for that purpose. The farming has not nor has it ever had anything to do with the school. Mr. Isaac Gibson certainly has too much knowledge of things to believe that the object of the Government is other than it is, and if he does not mean what he says when he makes the above statement then he should be more explicit.

To the second part of the above statement he is, I am afraid, again quoting as facts hearsay, for be it understood Mr. Isaac Gibson has only been in business at the 150 mile House for about one year and consequently cannot know what he states to be facts as there is absolutely no truth in the statement. There never was any attempt on our part other than the usual to interfere in business with our neighbours nor have we ever had any such attempt quickly terminated, as he says, by your predecessor. I wish to state that his assertion that your predecessor is false as we never officially knew other than yourself and had no official correspondence on this nor other subject with any other, for the simple reason that there was no school in William's Lake for Indians and your predecessor but it is not...
have made the above statement as all his other are on a par with this one.

Mr. Gibson says: "But it is nevertheless a fact this mission people allow their cattle to die of hunger in full view of dry stacks of hay because they think they can possibly make a few more dollars by selling their hay than by feeding the poor starving cattle."

Mr. Gibson makes this assertion as a fact, consequently he must be alluding to last winter, and if does not mean last winter, he must again be stating not facts but hearsay. Our loss last winter was only one head; and this same gentleman last spring came to us to purchase fat beef, but unfortunately we were not able to accommodate him with any as we required all we had for our own use.

Before closing this letter I wish to say that we have had an irregular sequel of accusations to answer from time to time, most of which on investigation have turned out to be without foundation but they nevertheless are to us a source of annoyance in the prosecution of our work, all fair minded men will unite in saying is being done well and good. We have erected good substantial buildings for the accommodation of pupils in our charge and while admitting that it was part of our obligations to do so, we must nevertheless claim credit for having put them up in such substantial, large and attractive manner. This object has been accomplished only after great sacrifice and economy on our part and not by any surplus earnings we may have made on the government's grant for I am certain that were it not for the aid we are receiving from our farm we could not be in the position of being able to conduct the Industrial as we have done in the past and as we are prepared to do in the future.

I wish to lay great stress on the fact that the school is conducted independently of the farm and the children are not utilized in the least on it.
than in the gardens and dairyery and the products of these two last named industries are not placed on the market but are consumed by the staff and pupils. The staff of the industrial school is under my immediate control and the same rule applies to the farm hands who are controlled by the manager of that branch but in no case does the farm manager assume any responsibility in the school affairs.

The water system in use here up to the present having been found to be defective we have at an estimated cost of three thousand dollars decided to put in a water system second to none in the district. This could not possibly be done from the earnings we make on the farm and as a result we have in this case to do again what we have been glad to do in the past viz: to take monies earned from the farm to effect our objects. These additional explanations I believe are appropriate to the occasion and are advanced in rebuttal to Mr. Gibson's arguments that our sole aim in our work was dollars and cents and show conclusively that the contrary is the case. I will again state that although we are paid but for fifty children we are actually keeping fifty-eight. Is this not charity? But possibly Mr. Gibson is not aware of this or many more facts which we could advance were we so disposed in our defense in this particular accusation.

But, Sir, we have the consolation of having to record here that although we have been on several occasions accused and impartial investigations have been instituted we have been always well treated by the officials with whom we have had dealings and as far as we know we have given or tried to give the best returns possible as we intend to do in future for the monies expended on the children committed to our care.

Dear Sir:

In compliance to a promise which I made to you some time ago, I take the liberty to express my views on the conditions of the Williams Lake Industrial School. In your communications of the 13th instant marked C15, X, 2, you state the various reasons which urged the Department to bring the matter of the management of the above named school to my attention with a view that a change for the better might be made.

It is in your communication that I have the honor to answer. I shall take up the paragraphs of the same one by one.

Let us to the dismissal of the trade instructor in the harness shop and of the Prefect, of outdoor work and discipline.

I do not know what reason the Principal put forth for asking the discharge of Mr. Horan, but I was aware for some time past that Mr. Horan could not remain long in the school and give satisfaction, unless he would abandon his pretensions to do as he pleased. I might mention that this is Mr. Horan's second engagement at the school, he having been obliged to resign in 1896, I believe for having taken too active a part in electioneering against the advice of the Principal: Revd. Mr. Lejeune. Mr. Horan was hired again in the fall of 1899.

Yours,

[Signature]
