last spring he took it upon himself to undertake the employment of Census Commissioner and left the school for three months. On the remark of the Principal that he could not do that, he answered that he had the authorization of the Indian Agent. The Principal should have acted with determination, and in my estimation should have made his hand in his resignation, if he wished to go counter to the rules of the school. On my remark that he should have done so, he said that he thought Mr. Bell had given his sanction to Mr. Moran's absence from the school. He would not dare offer any objection; besides being recently arrived as Principal, and having already been criticized for having made another employee do his duty, he thought it preferable to tolerate Mr. Moran's action. It is well to state here that Mr. Moran is well known in the district and exercises some influence with some people.

The Principal found out later on that Mr. Bell did not sanction Mr. Moran's absence from the school at the time that he began his census tour.

Lately Mr. Moran made himself obnoxious to the proprietors of the 150 mile house and, naturally, the school would suffer from it. Again he owed some important bills for articles bought by and for himself, and delaying the payment thereof was incredible to an employee of the school which paid him a good salary. As to Mr. Brophy, Prefect of our door work, he has disgraced himself twice by going to the 150 mile house, the second time without leave, and then gambled and intoxicated himself.
His second absence lasted three days. The Principal was in duty bound to discharge him, first because Mr. Brophy was an employee of the School, secondly because of the scandal to the Indians.

The Department might here ask why not get better men? We have tried to get the best we could find for the sum money. The present teacher and Mr. Brophy were hired at Ottawa, purposely. Up to this Mr. Brophy had done very well, and Mr. Fulop, the teacher, gives satisfaction.

We have to labor under heavy odds, in a district which it is hard and expensive to reach and in which a man accustomed to the social conditions elsewhere, finds it still harder to live. Here's when a young man has realized a little money, he returns to civilization. The temptation to drink is stronger on a man when he is isolated, and the trouble consequent therefrom for the Principal, is increased. You are sufficiently aware of the truth of my remarks on this.

And as to the number of pupils which the Department was asked to discharged last November. Some of these pupils had been at the school for eight years and were anxious to leave it; but instead of going the right way about it, went the wrong way. The older ones drew a few of the younger ones with them. This escapee process began a year ago last November, under the incumbency of the former principal, Rev. Fr. MacKinnon. The symptoms of a serious determination to leave school, especially on the girls' part were deep set and it was evident for any one who was acquainted with the Indian character, that they would try again. Many measures were tried but to the only purpose of setting
the Indians, as a whole, against the school. The spirits having been once aroused, it was not easy to allay them. Gentleness was tried with the result that, with the exceptions of an occasional lull, the run always became frequent, always under leaderships of those larger girls. During my visit to the Indians of the district in the fall, I saw most of those pupils who had thus failed. To my questions they answered either that they wished to go home, as they had been long enough at school, or that one of the other girls had asked them to go with her, or that the teachers were cross and other equally childish reasons.

Indian parents are too easy on their children, and they believe too willingly what their children tell them. Hence some of them become the abettors of the truancy. When it was rough the parents it was more relative. When the children saw that they were upheld, they launched forth with more vigor; it came to such a pass that it was considered cowardly for one not to run away. Now when we consider the surroundings of the Williams Lake School and the cleverness of the Indian youths to hide, it is easy to realize how a set of determined children could defy the strictest vigilance, and carry out their well laid plans. I must say, however, that beyond the running away no child became guilty of any grievous misdemeanor. It was quite serious enough as it was. During my visit with the Indians in October I spoke to them on their duty with regard to the school. All showed a good spirit.

As a practical conclusion the principal culprit
amongst the children had to be removed from the possibility of giving bad example again, hence the request for the discharge of such a number at the time.

Since then the girls have improved perceptibly, of course greater care was taken than ever to remove all reason, either of complaint or disorder. You may well imagine the concern the previous state of affairs gave to all those who had any interest in the school.

As to the accusation of the lax management,

One of my reasons when I asked the Department a year ago, to allow a change of Principals for this School was precisely to insure a better discipline in the Institution. I am convinced that the present principal has the qualities of a good disciplinarian and his work so far proves it. Any one may come to the school at any hour and find good order & cleanliness in all of the Departments of the Institution.

Then why this disposition of the children to run away? Some of the pupils had begun their pranks before the present principal came in office. In the foregoing lines I have analyzed the symptoms of the disorder and it is apparent that it was not with the arrival of the principal that the truancies began. There was even a good few months before the truancies were repeated. I think that the girls were determined to carry out their intentions in spite of any body.

As to the boys, only a few ran away during the summer. True the principal insisted with the employees that they should do their duty. A refectory, Mr. G. Veil, seeing that he was repeatedly found in fault, asked to go. He did not appreciate the principal's way of doing
business. He had been accustomed to do a little as he pleased. Later on Mr. Bridger, the teacher, also left, giving for reasons that he could beat his position but in reality I think that was not his motive.

He did the boys harm by talking to them about the Father's want of love for the Indians etc. He also made the boys write to their parents to complain. This man was instrumental in putting an idea in some of the boys heads that they were big enough and that they could earn money if they left the school, and that the school was keeping them to get work out of them. I might also mention that the previous principal, Rev. Mr. Roycevin was deservedly popular with the white people, as a whole, and his removal was not liked; his successor had to suffer a time as a consequence of a measure to which he was a stranger.

You know the conditions of the country up there to realize that such a state of mind is possible with the people. Besides there have been, to your knowledge periodical attacks on the Mission folks by people who were urged by motives other than love, either for the Mission, the school or the Indians. Everything that happened at the school is subjected to their criticisms and blame is cast on the Fathers. Naturally the new principal came in for a part and without being known, was described as a hard man. His opinion is turning in his favor.

As to law among us regards ethical training, I do not know the exact meaning which is intended by "ethical training". If it means moral training, I must say that the children are no worse than
other children of the same race and class. Everything is done to inculcate the principles of religion and morality and to watch the practice thereof.

It is more true to say that the stricter these moral directions are attempted to have enforced, the more Indian children will find the school irksome.

I will conclude: Indians, although desirous of profiting of the benefits of which the schools are intended to confer, feel the strain of remaining long at the task very severe. Children surely feel more than their parents, and parents are too tender hearted to correct their children when they complain.

Indians have a holy horror of anything which smacks system and order. Now these are precisely the things which have most to be insisted upon in a school. Hence the opposition found in those who are to be benefitted by the training. It is not a subject of wonder for me that we find the greatest difficulty in dealing with the Indians from that habitual and innate disposition to shirk what is so disagreeable to them. They do not realize the weakness in their character and point it out to conclude that when Indian children are brought face to face with the necessity of going against their hereditary inclinations to indulge in their love for independence and are restrained in their habits of disorder, it is not surprising that they should wish to throw off the yoke of discipline.

I trust that this difficulty which has arisen in the Williams Lake School will be thoroughly and impartially examined by those whose part it is to do so, and that responsibilities shall be fixed on those who deserve them.
them. If it is the management, then I am willing to allow a change.

I beg to assure you that I am ready to receive suggestions as to what should next be done. These suggestions could, of course, be offered only after a thorough sifting of the whole affair.

Dear Sir:

I beg to draw your attention to a matter touching your Department which deeply concerns ourselves.

The St. Joseph's Mission which as you are aware is heavily subsidized by the Dominion Government every year has seen fit to go into trade and cut prices and compete against outside traders who are not receiving government assistance. While they confined their attention to stock-raising no objection was lodged by us but now that they have gone into a regular trading business we think it is time that something is done to interfere and prevent if possible the gross injustice of subsidized traders being allowed to compete with those who receive no assistance from the Government. The St. Joseph's Mission have a large
large warehouse & blacksmith-shop at a point called
3 Mile Creek some 3 miles down the waggon road from
this point, and here grain and hay are supplied and
sold through their agent at the blacksmith shop, cutting
prices to an absurd figure and making a profit which
they are enabled to do owing to their Government
subsidy.

The obvious unfairness of allowing
government assistance to parties to compete in trade
needs no comment. The matter was once previously
attempted by those same mission people but was
quickly terminated after it had been brought to the

you can interfere in the matter for us and I would
prefer if possible that the matter was terminated
quietly. I understand the Bishop is a fair-minded man
and would doubtless take a fair view of the matter
and see that we have no further cause for complaint.

The mission people now have a harness-shop, butcher-
shop, hay and grain stores besides benefitting from
the newly erected Blacksmith's shop at 3 Mile Creek
although by acting through an agent they may pretend
to
pretend to be disinterested in the Blacksmith's shop, while benefiting from all these sources they will not so much as help a siwash by allowing him the slightest credit either for food or seed grain and hence take none of those risks which are forced on all other legitimate traders and of course they use their religion to secure cheap labor and other assistance.

It is perhaps rather a hard thing to say of any one but it is even worse when it concerns an industrial establishment but it is nevertheless a fact that the mission people allow their cattle to die of hunger in full view of big stacks of hay because they think they can possibly make a few more dollars by selling their hay than by feeding the poor starving brutes, such wanton cruelty is surely not a good object lesson to the young people committed to their charge and for whose education the institution is so handsomely subsidized.

I feel sure that a few words from you will be sufficient to terminate our grievance and remove all cause for any complaint from us.

Johnny Sticks of Alkali Lake Rancheria deposed as follows—I. I am the father of the deceased Duncan Sticks. He was 8 years of age—he was at St Joseph's Industrial School for the last 3½ years. I was glad for him to be at the school. He ran away from the school about a year ago, and was found on the road and brought to the Rancheria—he had two companions with him. He gave as his reason for running away that he did not get sufficient food—and that they whipped him too much—he said he was beaten with a quirt—he said the food was bad and he could not eat it, and he was allowed no other food until he had eaten it. He was sick when he arrived home—and when he got better I brought him back to school—I made no complaint to the fathers at the Mission about his treatment. I last saw him alive in July at the school—he seemed well and happy—the next time I saw him was on Monday the 10th February last about 6 o'clock in the evening, a mile and a half this side of Harry Felker's Ranch. He was lying 75 yards off the road in the snow—he was quite dead, but not frozen. His hat was lying about one yard away, and he had marks of blood on his nose and his forehead—the left side of his face had been partly eaten by some animal. I picked up the cap, and saw marks of fresh blood on the inside, and thought it came from his nose—the body was
was then brought on a sleigh to my house—I saw his tracks on the road for about 600 yards from where he lay—there seemed no other track except that of the man who first found the body—I concluded he had died of hunger and cold—I received no word from the Mission that any boy had run away—if I had I should have gone at once and hunted for him—he ran away from the Mission about one o'clock on Saturday and must have been dead for nearly 2 days when found.

March 1st 1902.

Anthony Boitano, residing at Spring House, deposed.

On Feb 9th, I was returning home, and I heard at the Onward Ranch that Duncan Sticks, a little Indian boy, who had run away from the Mission the previous day was lost. I looked out for his tracks and first saw them where the road forks about two miles below Harry Felker's. There was no other track, and I kept on the road until I struck his track again on this side of the bridge crossing Chimney Creek. I kept following the track which appeared to have been made the night before for about a mile and a half beyond the bridge, until I found the boy's body lying under a tree, about 70 yards from the road. He was lying on his face, and his hat was lying under his face—there was blood on his cheeks, and behind the ears, and a portion of one cheek had been eaten by an animal—the body was not frozen stiff, but was quite cold and he appeared to have been dead for some hours. I noticed some blood on his cap, and I now identify the cap produced as the one he was wearing. I turned the body over on its back and recognized it as that of Duncan Sticks. I left the body in that position and came home and told my father about finding it.

I then rode on to Alkali Rancherie and told the boy's father that I had found him dead by the road-side and I went on and told the rest of the Indians.

150 Mile House, B.C. March 3rd, 1902.

Rev. Henry Boening, Superior of St Joseph's Industrial School and Mission said: Took charge there on March 6th, 1901; the first time any boys ran away was in the following May, and since then they have continued running away all the time. I believe more boys run away now than formerly, but can give no reason for it. I have never had complaints from any of the boys as to being punished too much, or being badly fed. Only in November last I asked the boys to give me any reason why they ran away, and Thomas Johnson was the only one who gave as his reason "the cat is bad." I asked the others if they found the food good, and they said "yes." Previous to that at the great meeting held by the Bishop & Fathers at Canoe Creek in October last, the Bishop had asked the children the reason they ran away so often—and some of them had stated it was on account of the food—on being asked for particulars the only article of diet they complained of was the soup which was sometimes given for breakfast during the week, as being the remnants of other meals. Since then orders have been given that the soup should always be made of fresh ingredients and to my knowledge no child has been given food left over from a previous meal. The porridge is made of ordinary oatmeal—and I have tasted it myself and am satisfied it is good and nourishing. Neither girls or boys have ever made any complaint to me that the meat was bad.

On
On two occasions I have found girls throw away meat under the table—the meat was good—I have also seen boys throwing pieces of bread about their dining room but I examined the bread and found it good.

I have never known the teacher punish the boys with undue severity or too frequently, and the strap which he uses I do not think too severe. I sometimes have occasion to administer corporal punishment to the boys myself for special faults, and I use a strap similar to that used by the teacher—I have used on perhaps 3 occasions a saddle whip or quirt to punish boys for immorality—I limit myself on these occasions to 3 10 or 12 blows across the back outside of the clothes on the seat, and on only one occasion have I punished several boys after taking off their coats and then used the ordinary strap. The punishment of the girls is within the discretion of the Sister Superior, but where I consider any punishment given to a girl excessive, I have authority to forbid or lessen it—no case has come to my knowledge of undue severity or punishment in either the girls or boys school, as far as I can remember. I have never known of a girl being confined alone in a room for a week, or being whipped with a strap across the face, at least since my arrival, though I am aware of such a case occurring in the past. No child has ever been confined in a dark room since my arrival, though I have heard from others that cases of the kind have occurred in former times. In my time no girl has been slapped across the face with a strap to my knowledge though I have heard from others that this has been done before my
heard from others that this has been done before my time. I have no knowledge of any girl either in my time or previous having been stripped naked and whipped. I have no idea why the deceased boy Duncan sticks should have run away on the 8th Feb nor was there any reason to my knowledge for the other boys running away. On returning to the Mission about 5 O'Clock I learned from Mr. Fahey that he had brought back Augustine and at the same time learned that Duncan Sticks was still missing. I asked Father Capini to go immediately to Sugar Cane and tell the Indians the names of the missing boys so that they might hunt for them but was not anxious about Duncan Sticks, thinking that as his companion was caught he would not dare go on by himself, but would return to the neighbourhood of the Mission and get in the shelter of some hay stack. I was out all night hunting after 4 boys belonging to Nanom Lake as one of them had lately been very ill and another had delicate lungs. On Sunday after Mass as nothing had been heard or seen of the deceased I got anxious about him, and got Father Capini to see if he could get some Indian to go after the boy, and he was promised by the Chief that someone would go after him, but am not aware if any one actually went. Between 4 and 5 o'clock Monday afternoon I was informed by the Chief from Sugar-Cane that the boy had been found dead, the other side of Felker's place at Chimney Creek. On Tuesday morning I came up to 150 Mile House and I asked Mr. Hall, the Justice of the Peace, if the ordinary law relating to a Coroner's notification...
notification applied to the Indians—he told me it did.

Afterwards I sent Father Capini up, who again asked Mr Hall if a Coroner should be notified, and Mr Hall replied that it would not be necessary, as the Coroner would not go on account of the distance and expense.

Mr William Thompson of Horsefly, a Coroner for this district was however notified by Mr Horan, of the Mission, and the present at the Mission at the time took no steps in the matter. Hearing that the Coroner would take no action I offered to go over to Alkali Lake and bury the body as the Indians had decided to bury him on Thursday. No complaint was made to me by the Father or Mother of deceased as to the boy’s treatment at the school. I saw the body of the deceased, and saw some wounds on his face which I was told had been caused by some animal after his death.

He had not to my knowledge any cut or wound on his face before he ran away. I considered he was in good health and should never have expected him to meet with his death at so short a distance from the Mission. I would myself have gone after the boy, but having been on foot all the time from one o’clock on Saturday afternoon until 7 o’clock on Sunday morning, excepting for 2 or 3 hours on Saturday night hunting after some of the other boys, I was too exhausted to do anything more, and had to leave it to others to go after him.

Witnessed by. (sgd) H. Boening.

150 Mile House, B.C. March 3rd, 1902.

Sister Euphresia, Sister Superior of the girl's school at St Joseph's Mission said.

I have been 6 years at the Mission, and during the first year the girls ran away frequently; then they stopped for a time and about November 1900 they commenced again to run away—they have never given me any reason for running away—sometimes they have complained that the food was not well cooked, and say they have too much and leave it on their plates, or throw it under the table, or put it in their pockets.

I have examined the food on these occasions and found it good and fit to eat. Sometimes I have found the soup not very good, but I have never known it to have a bad taste. The porridge for breakfast once or twice a week is made of shorts, and tastes good—other mornings it is made of oatmeal—they get bread and tea besides and on Sunday morning they get Sausage and butter on Friday—the girls have sometimes to be whipped with a strap—generally on the back, sometimes on the hands, and on the occasion when Ellen Batiste was hit on the head, she raised her hands to her head and the blow took part effect on the head unintentionally—I found fault with the Sister on that occasion and I believe it has never occurred since. Sometimes girls are shut up in a room for serious faults for periods varying from a few hours to 10 or 12 days—this is the longest time—this latter has only happened once, they are fed on bread and tea, or water at breakfast when confined as above and get the ordinary

Girls are sometimes punished by being made to kneel on the ground for 5 or 10 minutes, but never longer than that—the rooms in which girls may be confined are never darkened. I remember saying to the girls on one occasion that the Government didn't allow enough money to feed them any better, but this was said in a joke. The blow which Ellen Batiste once got on the head raised a mark on her ear and cheek but didn't cut her.

I always see the food given to the boys—it is always good and plentiful.

I have been employed at the Mission for the last 2-1/2 years and am conversant with the working of the general rules and regulations. I, S.E. Motyn Hoops, Physician and Surgeon, residing and practising at 150 mile House Cariboo, B.C., and acting as Coroner in the enquiry into the cause of death of Duncan Sticks lately a pupil at St Joseph's Industrial School declare that on Friday the 28th February 1902 I directed the body of the deceased boy to be exhumed at Alkali Lake, where he had been buried, and together with the Jury made an examination of the body. It appeared to be that of a fairly well nourished boy about 9 years of age. The body had no bruises or injuries of any kind; the limbs were also free from injury. On the left side of the face on the upper part of the cheek bone, the flesh had been eaten away by some animal, for a space about one inch in diameter. There was a small wound on the upper part of the forehead, about one third of an inch in extent, crusted by blood—small patches of blood were also found over one eye, and on the left cheek, and some traces of blood were found behind both ears; there appeared to be also a slight bruise on the forehead. The wound or bleeding were not sufficient to cause death, and appeared likely to have been caused by stumbling or slipping and falling against a tree or rock, but did not appear to have been caused by any weapon. I examined the clothes worn by deceased at the time of his death, they were all free.
free from traces of blood, with the exception of the cap, on which were several blood stains and a small quantity of coagulated blood. I am of opinion that death was due to cold and exposure, from sleeping out at night in cold weather with insufficient clothes and without food or fire—exhaustion from a long tramp over the mountains in the snow was no doubt a predisposing cause.

(sgd) S.E. Mostyn Hoops.

The Secretary:

Memo. re management of Williams Lake school.

The exceedingly lax management of this school was brought to the notice of the Department last month by Mr. Supt. Vowell, who forwarded correspondence had with the Principal and Mr Agent Bell relative to an application for the discharge of nine pupils on the ground of frequent desertions. Their discharge was authorized, as it was claimed that they set a bad example to the younger pupils and to relieve the Principal of their dangerous presence in the school.

On the 13th ultimo, Mr. Supt. Vowell reported the death of a pupil named Duncan while absconding from the school and stated that he had instructed Mr Agent Bell to visit the school at once and investigate into the circumstances leading to the boy's death. The Department approved of Mr Vowell's action saying that it hoped Mr Bell would, by careful observation and close enquiry, be able to place the true state of affairs at this school before it.

Mr Bell's report has just reached the Department from which it will be seen that he does not consider that there was any good reason for the desertions as the pupils are well fed and cared for. The school is, however, he states, short-handed and the Principal is not at all popular with the children. This is the result of Mr Bell's enquiry, and it is not
not satisfactory, as he make no suggestions as to how matters might be improved.

Mr Supt. Vowell is at present making a tour of inspection of the Fraser and Kamloops-Okanagan Agencies and as he will be passing Ashcroft it would be well if he had the time to visit Williams Lake personally.

An inquest is to be held to enquire into the circumstances leading to the death of the pupil Duncan, when, no doubt, further facts will be brought to light.

The school should not, however, be allowed to go on as it is and you will see from a copy of a letter from His Lordship, Bishop Dotenwill, hereunder, that he is most anxious to have the management thoroughly examined into and willing to make any changes that may be suggested.

MEMO.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that, in compliance with the desire of the Department that I visit Williams Lake School and make full inquiry into the management—as per telegram dated 14th ultimo,—I visited the school mentioned on the 24th ultimo. I arrived at the 156 mile house, some four miles distant from the school, early in the afternoon and although, as far as my knowledge extends, the management was not advised of my coming still as the people residing in that vicinity, most of whom are adverse to that function, are in the habit of expressing their opinion that the coming of the Agent or myself is always known at the same beforehand, I considered it best not to proceed at once to the Mission but to let it be thought that I would go there till next morning. I consequently, and apparently with this intent, remained at the 156 mile house till after 5 p.m. and then drove quietly to the school so as to arrive in time to find the children at their evening meal. I did so and found the young people partaking of their ordinary food which upon examination I found to be good and wholesome. It consisted of soup with bread and rice in it, boiled beef and bread, with tea and sugar. The children appeared in the best of health and spirits and most certainly not indicating by their looks that there was any scarcity of food. The children are always pleased to see me, and look upon me as their friend; I went amongst them and asked if they always had as good a supper and if the food was all—

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
always as good and sufficient and they smilingly told me it was. After inspecting other departments which I found equally satisfactory I returned to the 150 mile house for the night. Next morning (25th) I returned to the school at an early hour when I examined everything in connection with the management carefully. In the boys class room I with the Indian Agent— none of the staff of the school being present— questioned the boys as to how they were treated, dealt with whether they were harshly, treated and if they always had enough to eat, etc., in response nothing could be elicited reflecting in any serious manner upon the management. The boys whose names appear in the evidence taken at the Coroners Inquest (copies of which have been forwarded to the Dept.) were particularly examined by me with the following result—

Augustin, aged 7, his only complaint was that he was whipped on the legs with a strap by the teacher for not knowing his lessons. When I asked him if he was much hurt he laughingly said he was not.

Louis, aged 13, said he ran away because the teacher whipped him on the legs, he was not badly hurt, said he had plenty to eat but that a long time ago he was sometimes hungry.

François, aged 10, also ran away because he was punished in like manner; said he had plenty to eat since Father Beening came to the school.

Tommy Johnson, aged 12, stated that he ran away because he did not get enough food, and also because he was whipped on the legs.

François, aged 10, repeated what the last boy said.

Upon questioning the boys generally as to the shortness of food it came out that sometimes some one or other of them did not get enough bread; I asked them if on such occasions they ever asked for more and they said they did not. I then told them that when they did not have sufficient bread they should ask for more and they would get it and explained
to them that many of the boys, as I had been informed, often get more than they could eat, the uneaten portion being wasted; and that in future if the piece of bread placed at each boy's plate was not sufficient that the Father or any member of the staff in attendance, upon request, would give them more; they then said that in future they would do so and seemed satisfied. They then after whispering among themselves for a time, said that they would like to get potatoes more frequently at their meals, and that that was all they had to ask for. I afterwards in their presence explained matters to Father Beening, both in respect to the bread and to the potatoes, and he said that certainly the Management would be only too pleased to do what they asked for, and what I suggested, and further that on no occasion had any pupil ever been refused an additional piece of bread, etc., if asked for. In the afternoon, with only the Agent being present, I questioned the girls, who were gathered together in their class room, with the following result:

Ellen Babtiste, aged 16, said that she had run away twice and was brought back each time; was whipped at school for talking to another girl; she had plenty to eat all the time. I asked her about being whipped on the head (as stated in the deposition before the Coroner) when she stated that when she was struck on the head with the strap she was holding her hands close to her head and that it was when endeavouring to hit her hands the Sister hit her on the head, which did not hurt much.

The other girls who had run away when questioned in doing so, said they had none, merely felt like running away, wanted freedom from the restraint of school discipline and wanted a chance to play with the boys, which they never had an opportunity of doing at the school. Before leaving I told both boys and girls how wrong it was to run away as by so doing they, to a certain extent, disgraced themselves by such bad conduct, and also caused much trouble to their parents, to their kind friends, instructors and guardians, at the school, and also the Government which was doing so much for them, etc., etc.

I also impres...
impressed upon them that if ever they had any real grievance they should at once mention it to the Principal, Father Boening, who was always kindly disposed towards them and did not want them to suffer in any way or to be uncomfortable; I further told them that if upon any such occasion arising they found that the Father did not help them that then they should tell their parents who would inform the Indian Agent, etc., etc.

They promised to do so, seemed sorry for the trouble they had caused by running away, and said they would not do so any more.

I may here mention that some dozen letters, mostly written by the girls to the boys, which were found at the school in the girls' desks after they had at different times run away, were produced by the Father (Principal) and that in none of them was mention made of bad treatment either in regard to punishment or to insufficiency or badness of food etc., etc. I was also shown letters from some of the pupils' parents—Fathers and Mothers—in which the Principal is asked to punish their respective children when they don't do what is right, etc. There were other communications written to the Principal by some of the pupils who had run away in which sorrow was expressed for the trouble and anxiety they had caused the Principal and the Sisters by their foolish conduct, etc., in none of which was there any mention made of their having received bad treatment at the School. As previously stated, the real reason given by the girls for running away was that they longed for freedom and for a chance to play with the boys, and such like foolish excuses. The boys, the big ones, wanted to get away because they thought they could get work and make some money; when the big boys ran off the smaller ones wishing to be considered brave and not afraid, etc., followed their example. It was the same with the little girls who I am told were often twitted by the older ones, the latter saying that their smaller companions dare not make the attempt. Touching the reliability of answers received from
from Indian children to questions put at random I may here remark that from my own observation outsiders asking questions can seldom really obtain correct answers inasmuch as the children, in most cases, don't understand exactly the nature of the question put from the fact that they are too timid and don't pay proper attention, etc. I have known them on such occasions to say 'yes' when it afterwards turned out that they would have said 'no,' did they thoroughly understand; consequently, as they are inclined to answer as they think you would like them to, if an outsider wants them to say that such and such a thing is the case it is an easy matter to get them to answer in the affirmative, or vice versa. It may also be mentioned here that there is much jealousy existing in the neighbourhood of the School in connection with the Mission people because the latter raise stock, hay and grain, etc., for the market, which others in the same line of business object to fancying that the Mission has in some way an advantage over outsiders. I have seen the punishment books and do not consider that the punishment awarded at various times was excessive. Letters written by Mr. Bridger and addressed to the Principal were also shown to me which were couched in the most friendly language; in one of these letters he begged to be taken back as teacher or if that position was filled then—to use his own language—he would be glad to go as warden or prefect, or in any capacity. Mr. Bridger, it will be remembered, was formerly a teacher at the school but voluntarily resigned that position on the 9th of June, 1891. As soon as he was clear of the Mission he at once commenced to make the most serious charges against the Management, etc., which he kept up all the way down the wagon road. While at the school I examined all departments carefully: dormitories, store rooms, kitchen, etc., etc., and found all in good order, well kept and clean. There was an abundance of food and clothing on hand in addition to which there was pleasing evidence of the skill of the girls in housewifery and in ordinary and fancy needle work, etc. I was busy all day at the school where every assistance was given me by the management to inspect and observe everything down to the minutest detail. I left for the 150-mile House at 6:30 p.m.
At 7:30 next morning (26th) I started for Alkali Lake—33 miles distant,—where at 2 p.m. I saw all the Indians at their village they being at the time gathered together for religious exercises under their Missionary Priest. They had no complaints to make about the school, expressed themselves as being sorry for all the trouble caused by the running away of the children from time to time; and promised to do all they could to put a stop to any future irregularities of the kind. I explained to them that if ever they knew that their children were not well treated they should notify the Agent, and if he did not attend to such complaints then to apply to me. They thanked me and said that they would be sure to do so. While at the village I questioned Christine Haines and Ellen Charlie who both persisted in stating that the meat was bad in the soup and that at times the bread was like putty. Ellen Charlie said she was whipped sometimes for talking to and looking at the boys; whipped on the hands mostly, sometimes her clothes were turned up. Regarding these girls it must be remembered that they were discharged from the school for bad conduct. At about 4 p.m. I left on my return when the Indians told me at parting that they were very glad to see me, and seemed highly pleased with my visit. Next day (27th) I arranged so as to get to the Mission unannounced by the time the children would be sitting down to their midday meal. I managed to do so and found the children partaking of roast potatoes and gravy, boiled rice sweetened, bread with tea and sugar; they had drippings on their bread which they seemed to enjoy very much. It being lent they had no meat. The staff as at present composed is as follows,—Principal, Father Beening, who has general supervision; Sister Superior, Euphrosia, now engaged as head teacher for the boys; this arrangement it is hoped will work well as the pupils know the Sister and will advance better under her instruction than under the teaching of a comparative stranger which owing to the many changes on account of
the difficulties experienced in procuring the services of an eligible male teacher has been too much the case in the past. The Sister Superior is also head teacher for the girls; their hours for instruction not being the same as that arranged for the boys there can be no confusion of duty in connection with the dual undertaking.

Sister Dennis, assistant teacher;
Sister Joannes, who is engaged in instructing the girls in needle work, knitting, making and mending the girls clothes, and in fancy work;
Sister Gonzales, prefecting generally;
Sister Fabrian, head cook and housekeeper;
Sister Glaver, assistant cook, etc.;
Mr. Fahey, agricultural instructor for the boys who being small are only capable of very light work;
M. Lajoie, carpenter.

There is no harness instructor at present. The Management is seeking for a suitable man to undertake the teaching of shoemaking and harness repairing, etc.

It is intended to put 4 of the boys (largest) at practical gardening on a piece of land especially provided for them where they will be taught the cultivation of grain, roots, the cutting and saving of hay and the raising of vegetables, etc.

This last mentioned work was not carried on to any extent last year the boys being so small and also owing to the fact that amongst a certain portion of the surrounding settlers and store keepers an outcry was raised to the effect that the Mission was making money out of the boys' labour which enabled crops to be raised more cheaply than outsiders could do, a most erroneous impression, as the work at any time done by the pupils could not reasonably be considered as a factor in the economic working of the Mission lands. I may here refer to the letter of complaint written by Mr. Carew Gibson, of the 150 mile house on the 23rd July, 1900, and to other correspondence.
correspondence of a like nature. In discussing matters with the Rev'd Principal he informed me that sometimes such of the boys as were given to wetting their beds were not allowed to drink water after supper; I told him that I thought it was bordering on cruelty to refuse a boy a drin of water if he was thirsty; he replied that in most cases they were not actually in need of a drink but took it out of mischief, etc.; he, however, promised that in future if any boy wanted a drink, saying he was thirsty, it would be given to him. I also suggested that corporal punishment should not be resorted to except in very extreme cases and that I thought good advice and kindly treatment would be far more effective in gaining their confidence and inducing them to pay proper respect to the school management, etc. The Principal remarked about the bread that sometimes there might be a batch that was not quite a success when it was doubtless a little doughy, this, however, did not often occur and when it did the Management fared no better than the pupils. As to the soup being thin and like water he granted that at times it might not have been extra strong but that always it was made out of good meat when it was stated that the meat was rotten such a state was not true as every care was taken to have things clean and sweet in every department. Later I examined the meat safes and found them clean and well ventilated. In this connection I must state that in nearly every instance the pupils said that since Father Boening came and took charge the food has been good, but that before his time on many occasions it was bad. In conclusion I would state that the inquiry held will I feel sure be beneficial in every respect as giving confidence to the children that they are being looked after by the Department and also in letting the Management understand that their actions in the conduct of the school are under close observation, etc.

MEMO.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that I returned to Victoria on the evening of the 13th inst., after an absence of 10 days in the Fraser, and Kamloops-Okanagan Agencies. On the 15th inst., as I was preparing to leave Vancouver for Victoria I received the Department's telegram of even date re my visiting William's Lake and inquiring into the management of the Indian Industrial School there situated. On the 14th, I wired "Returned last night, will write inclosing depositions re Coroner's Inquest." On yesterday a copy of the depositions was duly forwarded to the Dept. under cover of letter dated 17th inst., No. 198, Y/3. The evidence of the pupils point to bad and unsatisfactory food, to undue punishment and to the restriction of water for drinking purposes. On the other hand the Teachers and those superintending the Management declare the food to be of good and wholesome quality, and abundant for all requirements. Judging, however, from the repeated and determined efforts to escape made by both boys and girls it must impress one with the belief that all is not well, especially as the pupils in other Industrial Indian Schools in the Superintendency do not seem to be so actuated; although at times (as there will be at all schools whether for whites or Indians) some one or other of the pupils may attempt to run home. I will in accordance with the wishes of the Department leave here on the 20th inst. and proceed direct to the school where I will endeavour to get at the bottom of the trouble. I, however, apprehend much difficulty in

I am very happy to be chosen amongst any civil companions to write you this letter and to wish you in this and my own name a prosperous and happy new year. I don't deserve that honour, but I will tell you that I placed me very much because you are, sir, very kind for Indian children. We had a merry Christmas that made us happy high mass had been said at midnight in our chapel by Father Superior and girls and boys sang during it, after mass we went in the school room where Santa Claus had passed he had a big basket full of candies and toys. There are some more coming on the road.

We are going to have examination very soon and Father Superior is going to give us some more tickets so we can buy whatever we like.

We are your grateful children.

In the name of all the girls of William's Lake Industrial School

Eliza Johnny.

Sir:

I beg leave to appeal direct to you in regard to a matter that we consider of the greatest importance for the welfare of this school. Dear Father:

It is not long time before I have not seen you, but I thought I would write you a little letter today. I am always happy though I feel lonesome when I think of you and my brother and sister. We came safely on the stage and on the boat, and Freddy brought us to his house so we stayed there for the night. It is pretty cold around here already and nearly all the vegetables are frozen. We see Jerome and Baptist pretty often they come to church nearly every Sunday. We began our studies a month ago already and the school year opens very nicely for everyone. I guess you are finished with your hay now, the hay around here is nearly all finished. Two or three weeks ago two automobiles came here, so some sisters and some girls had the pleasure to take a ride in it. They went to the yellow lake near the mission. Please tell us where Juliana and Jimmy are staying now. And about Alice and Jimmy if they are well or not. I suppose all the steamers are running on the river yet except the poor...
Charlotte who is drowned. We picked pretty much berries this year. Sarah found her umbrella at 50-Mile House, and another thing when we came back Sister Superior gave us two thimbles as a present.

I have no more news, hoping you are well. I send my best wishes to all and a kiss to Alice.

From your loving daughter
Anne J. Baptist.
Dear Father:

I thought of writing you a letter today, though I have not much news to tell you. I am always in good health. It made me sad to hear that you were not all very well. But I hope you will soon be well again.

Eulalie from Stuart's Lake died on August 23rd. She was brought from 150 to Soda Creek in an automobile with Father Superior and another girl who accompanied the sick girl. From Soda Creek Father took the steamer. When they arrived at Fort George it is said she was sinking lower and lower. Father came back on Tuesday night, on arriving at 150 he found a telegram there. The poor girl was dead. In the morning Father said high mass for her. There is nobody sick here now.

We enjoy our time very joyously. Summer is lonesome for I have so much playmates. And besides the Fathers and Sisters are always kind and good to us. As I already told you I had not much news. I close my letter with all my best wishes for you.

Your affectionate daughter,

Rosy Louis.
Dear Father:

It is not very long since I have left, but I am a little lonesome without you. I am happy all the time for I have a lot of playmates here at school. We arrived here on the 3rd of August, we have passed by the Sugar Cane road to come back, and we were tired before we reach. A few days after we arrived Sister Superior gave us something because we came back on the third and count it just the same time as the other girls. The mission girl was sick and so she went home, and died on the 21st of August. Thursday afternoon, she was from Sturats Lake, we all prayed for her. Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter marked 117123/1 and dated November 29th, 1910 with reference to a remark in Mr. Inspector Green's report on this school, so that XXXXXX no boy has been employed in the fields the reason given being that I say that the Indians and white settlers living near object to the pupils working on the farm.

I very much regret on account of pressure of work I was unable to answer this letter before Christmas.

Now, however, I beg to state first that this fact of the boys not being employed in the fields ought not to be understood as being general and universal, it being an exception only and particular to last year's two seasons: summer and fall. All my reports in the blue book lay special stress on our efforts to give the boys a good training in agriculture.

Why, then, were the boys not employed on the fields this year?

On September 6th I wrote the Department stating that since their return from the holidays the boys had more or less all been running away from school; that, as this was an extraordinary thing for them to do and not being able to get an explanation either from them or their parents I respectfully requested the Department to send somebody here to hold a special inquiry.

A few days later there being a new breaking away I immediately sent a telegram to our Indian Agent, Isaac Ogden, living only 33 miles from here.
and requested his presence here. This telegram gave occasion to some correspondence between him and myself of which I herewith enclose true copy so, letter of Indian Agent dated Sept. 12th, letter of myself dated Sept. 28th enclosing letters of pupils: Modest Charlie and Lizette Theodore, both dated Sept. 18th.

In my telegram, however, I did not say as mentioned in the Agent's letter: "the children have run" but "the children are running" and my reason for calling the Agent by telegram was that, of the many who wanted to break away, only one succeeded and the others being held here it would have been an easy task for the Agent to get at the bottom of the affair.

Such then being the boys' dispositions would it have been wise on my part to expose them to still greater chances of escape by allowing them out on the fields or was I not rather justified, in order to prevent greater harm, to choose the lesser evil by keeping them near me? What a cry would have gone up both from the Indians and the white settlers had the boys escaped when forced to work at hoeing for example? In our long experience here we have met with the most absurd accusations not only from Indians and envious white settlers but even from such as we thought friendly disposed, yes, even from employees who knew better. The enclosed correspondence gives you a fresh instance of how an innocent word can be twisted and easily even a false accusation meets with success.

The fact is that the Indians of this agency are ignorant about the purpose, the working and benefits of the school. How could they know?
I am therefore much pleased with the Department's assurance that "the Agent and the Inspector will cooperate with me in seeing that the wishes of the Department are carried out." The Agent's authority as Government officer, we know, is very great among the Indians. If then, after previous understanding with the principal, on his customary visits to the reserves he could make it a point to see as many Indians as possible and would speak to them about the school, its necessity and benefits to them, I am sure the task for us would be much lighter and the good still more apparent.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

H. Bening

Principal.

Dear Sir:-

I received your wire, and am sorry cannot go up just now. I got permission from the Department allowing me three weeks holiday and have made arrangements to take my son down at once to Victoria, and will be away about two weeks. I cannot see where I can do much good by going there, as you say the children have run. I think a closer watch should be kept on them.

I saw the Kanes Lake children both times going back from their runaways. I questioned Modest first time and he complained of the carpenter growing or annoying him in some way. I told him he should report anything of that kind to you but not to run away; he also told different stories to outsiders stating that he was not well enough fed.

I made inquiries from some of the Indians coming from Alkali Lake today and they inform me that children have not run away from there, but Wyott's daughter has not yet returned to school and she complained to her father about the grub.

I have written the Indian constables stating it's a part of their duty to see that children return to school as soon as they run away. I will be away about two weeks and on my return will proceed up there.

Your obedient servant,

Isaac Ogden,

Sir:

I received your letter of 12th inst., informing me that it was impossible for you to come here as requested by me in order to look into the matter of the repeated runaways among the boys.

I must, however, take exception to your statement that a closer watch should be kept on them. This implies that, if the children run away, it is on account of want of supervision. Now nothing could be further from the truth than this. It is not after nine (9) years I have been with them that I would have requested your cooperation in. I have been conscious of not doing my duty in this regard. We are all very pleased at such kindness.

Not less pleased have we been by what the two pupils, Modest Charlie and Lisette Theodore, are reported to have said. My answer, however, to these two points is made the easier by the letters, herewith attached from each of the two pupils. And I wish to state expressly that these letters have not been dictated to them but are their own work.

I notice that you have reminded the Indian constables of their duty in seeing that children who escape from school return thereto as soon as they run away.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the request of Rev. Father Welch, O.M.I., for an increased per capita grant from 50 to 70 pupils at the Williams Lake Industrial School I beg to say that similar applications have been received during the past.

In 1907 Mr. Green, the late Inspector of Indian Schools, recommended that the pupils drawing the grant should be increased to 80 and with regard to the accommodation the late Inspector Gummiskey stated that he did not hesitate to say from the way the school-rooms are planned and the amount of fresh air that can be run through them at short intervals that they are capable of accommodating 90 pupils. Besides the regular grant earners this school has a number of children in residence for whom no grant is paid. The buildings in connection with the school comprise a main building and residences for the boys and girls and also a building which contains the kitchens and dining room.
Mr. Inspector Cairns, who inspected this school in May, last, states that, while, the grant is allowed for only 50 pupils, there is generally more than this number enrolled and there is no difficulty in keeping up the attendance. The pupils all come from the Williams Lake Agency. They have an abundant water supply, which is brought from an artificial lake by means of wooden pipes and there is also a good drainage system. The only means of ventilation is through the windows and doors. The buildings are heated by hot air and lighted by acetylene gas. A new railway is under course of construction which passes through the farm. This gives direct connection with Vancouver to the South West and Fort George to the North.

I would suggest that, as the Department has no particulars regarding the size of the school or the dormitories, either Mr. Inspector Cairns or the Agency Inspector, Mr. Megraw, be instructed to furnish a report on this matter.

Sir:

I beg to enclose the ANNUAL REPORT of the Cariboo Industrial School, for the fiscal year ending March 31st, 1923, trusting that you will find it in order and according to the requirements of the Department of Indian affairs.

I would like, Sir, to call your attention to the item marked DEPOSIT in the Financial Statement. It was $12683.44 at the end of the fiscal year ending March 31st, 1923, and at the end of the present fiscal year there is a further sum of $3715.62 to be added.

Any remark about it would be out of place in an official report, but will naturally find its place in an explanatory letter.

We have tried to reduce to a minimum the expenses of running this school, having however due regard to the health and material comfort of the children, and the new deficit is ENTIRELY due to the necessity of providing for them. No extraordinary expense has been incurred for the school during the last fiscal year, and the high cost of living is alone responsible for that item.

I must add that unfortunately we are facing another heavy but necessary expenditure for the next fiscal year.

Last December, some mischievous muskrat blocked the INTAKE of our school WATER SYSTEM during a very cold spell, and before we could have noticed it, the water pipes were frozen between the INTAKE and the RESERVOIR behind the school buildings on a distance of at least one mile. Since that time we have been compelled to carry water to the school, every day, from the creek. The Water System must of all necessity be repaired as soon as the ground is sufficiently thawed out; the difficulty of the present unsatisfactory way of taking water from the creek, and more so the children's health demand it imperiously.

I foresee an expense of at least $2000.00 to do that work. But where shall I find money? It causes me to worry.

I would hate to make any suggestions or to appear begging, but I feel, Sir, that something ought to be done on our behalf.

I think that all that is done here at our school, and what is proposed to be done is ENTIRELY for the benefit of the children who are the wards of the Government; we have in view their material interests as well as their spiritual, and in our case, in view of our present difficulties a little further MONETARY ASSISTANCE from the Department of Indian Affairs would be much needed and most welcome.

I beg to remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

L. Choinel
Principal

I do not think he was cruel, as we understand it in college in our day, but the lower you go in the human strata the more delicate the susceptibility apparently becomes, and what would not appear out of the way to a Duke's son in the way of discipline would entail great hardship and outrage upon that of a working man or an Indian.

Bro. Joseph carried in his hand a rod and with this he then and there flogged the boy and made him apologize for his rudeness. In doing this the Disciplinarian was breaking the rules of the school. He should have reported the matter to the Principal.

That night this boy ran away from school. He never was brought back.

It is admitted that the Disciplinarian did wrong in taking the matter in his own hands. It is not admitted that the boy was too severely punished for such a serious offence. The punishment should fit the offence.

Sir,

Conduct of Williams Lake School.

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter #117,123-1a of the 9th inst., asking for a report from me in regard to undue severe corporal punishment at the above named Institution.

In this connection, I already informed you of a complaint which had reached me, (my letter of the last inst.), and asked that authority might be wired me to have a medical examination made of the boys before they went home for the annual vacation.

The reason I asked for this was that it appeared the only way to obtain direct evidence that the abuses complained of existed, as the children would never own up to such treatment if called as witnesses at an investigation, unless we had first direct medical testimony that certain given children bore the marks of too severe beating. These upon being called upon to explain how and where the marks were received, could hardly fail to give testimony.

It is now too late for this, and by the time the holidays are over, it will be very difficult to do much, and I can only suggest that the Department allow me to visit the various Reserves, and in their own homes question all School children.

In going into such a matter, it must be remembered that in fairness to the School authorities, Indians are very much averse to restraint of any sort, and are not at all careful of what charges they may make against anyone who incurs their displeasure.

On the other hand, from my own personal knowledge of Mission conditions in the past in other places, the fact that it is a Religious organization of any sort running the place does not by any means place it above suspicion, and in fairness to the poor
Children who are committed to the mercy of the missionaries for several years of their young lives a thorough and at the same time unbiased investigation ought to be made. To do this properly, without first having medical evidence will be very difficult, as anything I can now find out will be unconfirmed statements of Indian children, against the testimony of the Church authorities, and to take action upon that will bring a religious hornets nest around the ears of the Department, unless the reverence in which missionaries are held in the East has undergone a great change since I lived there.

The general Indian attitude towards Mission Schools throughout Central B.C. is not friendly, and they are very much more in favor of Department run day schools in each Reserve.

So far as this is concerned, there is no doubt that the money spent annually by the Department #### in connection with each of the Missions I know anything about, would go far towards providing day schools in every Reserve in each of the Agencies concerned, and all the children would receive education instead of the very small proportion which is now the case. The Agricultural end of the education would be met by the appointment of a competent Farm Instructor in each Agency, and in any case, the Indians work so much upon white ranches that they acquire a knowledge of up to date farming automatically in the course of their work, and would really only need the Instructor as a "prod" to make them apply the principles they already know, to their own lands.

I may also say in connection with the School question, that the Missions in the Lytton and Williams Lake Agencies with which I am familiar do not play the game with the Department, as they take entire credit with the Indians for the educational facilities offered. Indians have told me time and again, in both Lytton and here, that the missionaries say they are at the entire expense of the Schools and that they receive no help from the Department. I have of course, disabused them upon that score, but it shows that there is something wrong in the attitude with which Departmental help is received, by the denominations concerned, and is one more reason why a more efficient service would be obtained under the direct control
of the Department.

I am quite aware that a good deal of this has not
a great deal to do, in one way with the question of the moment, but
I wish to bring both sides of the Mission School question to your
notice. On the one hand, we have the great tendency to lying upon the
part of the Indians, and on the other we have a decided lack of some-
thing upon the side of the Missions.

To make a really proper investigation under these
circumstances, we should have had had the medical examination asked
for by me, and without it we will be very much at a loss. However,
if you think it in order, and will advise me accordingly, I will go
over all the Reserves, and take what statements I can get, and send
them in to you, and you can then decide what further action you wish
taken.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Williams Lake, B.C. Agency.

Sir,

Conduct of Williams Lake School.

I have the honor to report in connection with my recent trip to the above Institution, that I received a complaint from a Canoe Creek Indian named Sam that the Disciplinarian of the School, Brother Joseph was much too free with his cane, and Sam wished to take his boy Wilfrid Basil away.

This in itself would not be very serious, as Indians are very much averse to any kind of restraint, and to put it mildly, are not to be believed, as a general thing when they complain about Schools or similar Institutions, as they let their imaginations run riot, if they think that by so doing it will help them to gain what they happen to want at the moment.

In this particular case, however, a boy ate poison hemlock, and died, while 8 more were very ill. The coroner was duly communicated with, but did not consider it necessary to hold an Inquest, as there was nothing suspicious about children eating a poison weed.

Sam however in making his request for the withdrawal of his son from the school says that the boys were in a very depressed frame of mind, and that the deceased boy said to the other 8, that he would eat the hemlock first and that they should eat after him. If this were true it would make what appeared an accident into a case of suicide.

I may as well say at once that I do not for one moment believe the story, but as you know anything of that sort will spread like wildfire among the Indians, and having been reported to us, it would appear that we should take some action to ascertain the truth of the complaints against this "Lay brother".

With this in view, I went up to the School, but the Acting Principal being away I could not do anything, and after talking...
the matter over with the Provincial Government Agent, to whom, in his capacity of Stipendiary Magistrate, the death of the boy was first reported, it struck me that it would be good policy to have a general medical examination of the school, previous to holding any sort of enquiry.

By this means we should know whether boys were unduly flogged as claimed by the Indian, and if the examination was held ostensibly for some other reason, such as to locate possible cases of Rupture etc., the School authorities would not be aware of what we were doing. Should the doctor find no traces of abuse, as I do not think he will, the matter can rest there, and we can ignore the complaint of the Indian.

Without in any way impugning the character of the school authorities, it is a matter of common knowledge that religious bodies carry what may be termed "Esprit de Corps" to an extent that would make it very difficult to place the guilt of one of their members unless we had in advance indisputable medical testimony.

While putting this matter before you, I would like to be quite plain that I do not think from what I have seen of the general conduct of the School in question that there is anything to the story, but in view of all the circumstances, I certainly do think that we should go into the matter.

We have no medical officer nearer than Doctor Wright at Alexis Creek. There is however a Railroad doctor, who used to be in the service of the Department at I think, Kamloops, named Dr F. Vere Anew, and I would suggest that this gentleman would be more suitable than Dr Wright for such an investigation.

As the usual School holidays will, I presume, take effect somewhere round the 15th inst., there is little time to be lost if you desire an examination to be made, and I would suggest that you notify me by wire if you think such a course advisable.

I may add that without a medical examination, to identify boys who have recently been flogged, it will be quite impossible to obtain any evidence as the fear of the Church would keep any youngster from coming forward.

Your obedient servant,

The Assist Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honour to forward herewith Inspection Report on the Cariboo Indian Residential School for the month of February 1930.

I visit this School several times in the course of the month, as a rule and, although the report is based on the actual class figures for one particular visit - in this case on the 26th inst.- the general remarks are the result of my observations throughout the whole month.

The girls were all employed in class-room work on my last visit but the boys were all outside. Owing to an exceptionally early thaw the snow has all gone and the boys were working at clearing up around the school, wood-yard and buildings. They had all been present at class in the morning.

I was glad to note continued rapid improvement in the manual training shop - some very creditable articles of woodwork are now being turned out and I hope to have a comprehensive display of such articles at the Fall Fairs this year. The boys draw the plans themselves and work from them in the correct manner and the instructor seems to be very competent.

There has been very little sickness at the School this winter, which speaks well for the general health and cleanliness of the place. I took the doctor out with me a short time ago and he gave attention to one or two minor troubles and two eye cases but generally speaking the pupils present a very well-fed appearance and are always smiling and cheerful.

The Sisters presented me with two large chalk-drawn landscapes done by the pupils which were very creditable and are now hung in the Agency offices.

As this School goes in considerably for live-stock and maintains a large farm the boys get invaluable training in the operating of machinery and the conducting of ranch activities which should be of inestimable value in later years.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that on the night of the 29th inst., I attended a concert given by the pupils of the Cariboo Indian Residential School. I thought you might be interested to hear of the excellence of the work and talent displayed by the pupils on this occasion.

All costumes, scene painting and decorations were made by the children, and formed a most creditable display.

The various items of the concert itself, were of a high order of merit, and compared very favourably with a similar concert staged by the white children of Williams Lake, a week previously.

The concerted singing evidenced very painstaking preparation on the part of the teachers, patriotic and other songs being rendered with clear melody and good enunciation.

A novel feature of the concert was a Punch and Judy show, built by the children who also painted the miniature scenery and manipulated the puppets. This was a most realistic effort and showed a great degree of imagination as also did the acting in the dialogues and sketches.

I took a party of friends from Williams Lake to attend this concert, as I feel that most people know very little about the work done by our schools amongst the Indian children, and to say that the visitors were surprised is putting it very mildly. There were repeated expressions of amazement at the standard of education and intelligence exhibited.

Nuts and candies were distributed amongst the pupils at the conclusion of the concert, and as they received a liberal number of toys and other good things on Christmas Day, I am satisfied that the holiday season was properly observed and very much enjoyed by the children of this School.

But to the Cariboo, the Indians are very glad that the government has taken a hand in the planning of road work in other parts of the province, and has made special arrangements for financing that scheme when we undertake it.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the question of additional accommodation for pupils at the Cariboo Indian Residential School is still a vital one.

There are a large number of very bright and healthy children amongst the Chilcotin bands of Indians who have at present no opportunity for any education. Last year a start was made with three Chilcotin children - these rapidly became accustomed to school life and now we have twelve Chilcotin children at the school, with many more willing to come in should the necessary accommodation be available. It was previously thought that the bringing of Chilcotin children to the school would never prove satisfactory and that they would not mix with the other Indians who speak a different dialect. This, however, is not the case - the Chilcotin pupils have proven most adaptable, and it seems a great pity to turn away more prospective pupils now that the way has been paved for them by the successful showing of the children from that area who have already been admitted.

I have discussed this matter with the school principal and he also is of the opinion that additional accommodation as early as possible is a vital matter if we are to retain the interest at present being shown in the school by the Chilcotin Indians.

This year the school built a manual training building with material supplied by the Department - the building is 24' x 50' and the principal suggests that two similar buildings be erected, one for girls and one for boys, adjacent to their present buildings. These would accommodate seventy-five pupils each and would be used for classrooms and for men's study rooms. The classrooms at present in use would then be released and available for dormitories and for sick bay, which the school is at present without.

This would enable the small pupils to be housed entirely on ground floors and would provide additional fire safety and less wear and tear.

The principal states that he would be willing to buy the necessary material and erect these two buildings if the Department will make a grant of $3,000.00 for the purpose. These buildings could be ready for occupancy by June 1931. As it will doubtless be some time before the Department will have funds for a new school for the Cariboo, this proposal would appear to be the best solution for further accommodation at present. I would be glad to know the attitude of the Department in this matter as soon as convenient.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H.E.TAYLOR)
Indian Agent.

I am enclosing a letter written to you by one of the girls in the name of all the children here in school. I gladly join with them in their Christmas and New Year's greetings.

The dormitory doors leading to the fire-escapes are never locked. It was only after they had made this offer that I told them that I would pay those who stayed. This building was put up almost entirely by the boys under the direction of the Manual Trainer who has 30 years experience as a Contractor. It was good training for them. Dear Sir:

I received your letter, dated April 30th over a week ago but wished to see Mr. Indian Agent Taylor before replying. I was unable to do so as when I went to see him I found that he had gone to Prince George in the interests of an Indian charged with murder.

It is perfectly true that we have not a trained nurse on the staff. I am not quite certain but I think that it was I who brought this to the attention of the agent about a year ago when the Provincial Superior of the Sisters was here. At that time I asked for a better qualified infirmary especially as the Sister in charge of this department was very ill at the time and not able to do much. So far, no change has been made but I intend to take this matter up again in about a month's time when the Superior General's first Assistant will be here. The main difficulty is that these Sisters are a teaching Order and have no hospitals. For other reasons, the principals to whom I have talked prefer this Order to other Orders in the conduct of Indian schools.

As for the present infirmary, she is not entirely incapable and the little training she had, together with several years' experience in looking after the sick children, appears to be enough to enable her to look after ordinary cases. I do not mean to say that I am satisfied with this nor do I intend to imply that Mr. Taylor misrepresented the situation. I might add that for the last three years there has been a duly qualified first aid man on the staff. As I was speaking to the Indian agent only of the infirmary, it is quite likely that I did not mention this fact to him. There is another point I would like to add but I do not know how to do so without appearing to criticize the Department. I as-
sure you do I have no intention of doing so. Two years ago two nurses were sent to work in this district in conjunction with Dr. Wall. After seeing them at work and listening to them at a clinic conducted for their benefit by Dr. Wall, I believe that our infirmary is better qualified than they apparently were. You will recall that, so soon as the facts were brought to the attention of the Department, these two nurses were dismissed.

I gave the Indian Agent a full report on the recent epidemic. A boy was taken to the hospital by the Doctor to have his tonsils removed. Next day two more were sent in to him for examination. The three were kept in the hospital by the Doctor and were reported to have pneumonia. There were a few more ill next day and, so as to avoid a hospital bill and to assure these boys of the best treatment, I got in touch with the Agent and the Doctor, and it was decided that a nurse would be the best solution especially as the treatment prescribed was to be given every two hours. For the same reason, the Doctor asked me to get help for the nurse who could not work 24 hours a day. Another reason for asking for a nurse was the effect it would have on the Indians, that this was a good move was shown by the remark made by the relatives of one of the boys who was very near death. "Look, they have a real nurse," the mother said even before sneaking to her son. This spread among the Indians and whatever fears they may have had were allayed. Had we not had a nurse and had there been any deaths, recruiting would have been very difficult, especially among the Chilcotins, for several years.

While the Nurse was in full charge of all the sick, the infirmary practically in charge of the girls. That she was able to handle the situation is indicated by the fact that the epidemic did not spread to them and that those who were ill (pleurisy, bronchitis, heart attack, severe colds) made rapid recoveries.

However, I would feel more at ease with a better qualified infirmary and will ask for one.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
