I am enclosing our annual report. It came rather late, in comparison with other years, and this, together with a slight indisposition, prevented me from sending it in sooner.

Our many addresses may be confusing. All letters and freight may be sent to the above address although there is no agent at our station. There is no danger of registered letters being lost because, even if they are sent to the above address, they will not be put off with the rest of our mail but will be taken to the 150 Mile Post Office. Express parcels are sent on to William's Lake. Even unprepaid freight is put off at our Station and, by arrangement with the P.G.E.Ryway and the Bank of Commerce, the amount due is collected from the Bank by the William's Lake Station Agent. Letters, etc., sent to William's Lake or to the 150 Mile House are delayed several days.

Trusting that this information will be of some use and thanking the Department for its courtesy and kindness, I remain

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Another year has rolled around, and consequently, another Christmas is at hand. I feel honored to be chosen from among my classmates to extend to you, in behalf of all the boys and girls of our School, our most sincere wishes for a Merry Christmastide.

We have all had the measles this fall, but with the watchful care of our kind Principal and staff we all have recovered and are once more well and happy in the school which has proved in many ways to be a second home to us.

Thank you for your Christmas greetings—a Merry Christmas—a Happy New Year to you. G. Jotham 8.7.1
At present we are one hundred and twenty-two children and I think all do their very best to profit by the different lessons given either in the classroom or during manual work, for we know that these things will be very useful to us when we leave school.

The boys with the help of the Carpenter are building a new laundry, they also make sturdy sleds and skis and do a certain amount of agricultural work. The girls cook, bake and during sewing class we make and mend all the girls' clothing, mend the boys' clothes, crochet, knit and do fancy work.

At present we are anxiously awaiting dear old Santa Claus and I must say, we try to be extra good so that he will not overlook any of us while out on his Christmas trip.

We have a very pleasant time at recess especially during the winter months. The boys have a skating rink where they play hockey against the neighboring camps. The girls have a number of big and small sleds and have just as enjoyable a time coasting down the hill.
Assuring you of our gratitude for the interest you take in our school we once more wish you a pleasant Christmas season and may 1938 be a year of prosperity, happiness and success for you and all dear to you is the sincere wish of.

Yours gratefully,

(Miss) Dora Steel.

AGENT'S REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR JULY 1944.

EDUCATION

The Mother General of the Missionary Sisters of Christ The King paid a visit to the Anaham and Alexis Creek reserves, looking over the possibilities for supplying teachers for the day schools.

Father Hennessy, has been appointed principal of the Caraboo Indian Residential school, temporarily, and Brother MacDonald formerly at Sechelt has been appointed disciplinarian. A good dairman who really understands the management of a dairy herd, theory as well as the practical side has also been engaged and it is hoped something can be worked out so that some of this knowledge may be imparted to the Indian pupils.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

Education;

The Cariboo Indian School appeared to be back to normal during the month and the school was closed for the holidays on July 2nd. The Provincial of the Oblates was written to asking that a disciplinarian and competent staff be procured before this school opens in the fall, otherwise the Agent would recommend that the School be closed.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1944.

Education:

The Cariboo Indian School put on a programme on Sunday evening, consisting of songs, dances, recitations and a display of Pro-Rec., which was very good and shows much improvement on past performances.

The boys at this school are now afforded much more liberty of movement and there have been less truancies for the past two months.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1944.

Education;

The pupils of the Cariboo Indian Day School put on a short program of songs and dances on Sunday, March 19th. The children are looking healthy and happy.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1944.

Education:

The pupils of the Williams Lake Superior School put on a Concert recently and thirty of the older children from the Cariboo Indian Residential School were brought in to see it with their teachers. Three of the local townspeople were kind enough to help with the transportation.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY, 1944.

Education;

There have been several cases of pupils running away from the Cariboo Indian Residential School during the month, no doubt due in some part to the fact that the disciplinarian, Mr. Sullivan, has been sick and is now convalescing in Vancouver. Father McGrath, however, expects another man to replace Mr. Sullivan in the near future, and it is to be hoped that truancy from this school will not be the problem during the coming spring and summer that it was a year ago.

During my visit to this school, the children all appeared to be well fed and happy, and I would say that the conditions, so far as providing sports and recreation are concerned, have improved to a very great extent since Father McGrath took over as principal. The pupils who ran away gave no valid reason for doing so. One girl, Anita Wycotte of Alkali Lake Reserve, was expelled during the month, and no doubt approval will be forthcoming from the Department after the circumstances are known.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH DECEMBER, 1943.

Education;

The Cariboo Indian Residential School was more or less back to normal by the Christmas holidays. Father Hennessy stayed at Alexis Creek Indian Day School over Christmas and put on a Christmas Tree for the children, the first they have know. He reports 28 children on the roll now, and most of them very enthusiastic.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

The Department is in receipt of a report from travelling nurse Garry with reference to the epidemic of mumps at the Cariboo Residential School. The Department realizes that while the staff at this school is no doubt putting forth their best efforts, the accommodation available is not altogether suitable. Consequently it would appear very inadvisable to allow the school to become overcrowded. This condition presents problems at any time and especially when there is an epidemic like the one at present. Dear Father Doran,

The Department has considered the application that has been made by the British Columbia Magnesium Co. Ltd., to explore and develop certain mineral deposits on the property owned by the Oblate Fathers in British Columbia, on which is located the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

I wish to inform you that the Department has no objection to an arrangement being entered into with the Company along the lines suggested in view of the fact that it is important in our war effort to assist in every way possible the development of all available deposits of strategic war materials, of which magnesium is one. It is understood that in your agreement with the company you will make provision for safeguarding as far as it is possible the carrying on of the operations at the school consistent with the reasonable exploration and development of the mineral deposit.

The Department agrees that the assistance or grants this school receives from the Government will not be affected or changed by reason of the agreement being entered into with the company and that the school will be entitled in the future to the same assistance that is or may be given to all residential schools. Should, for any reason, the mining operations make it necessary or advisable to close the school and to re-establish it elsewhere similar assistance will be granted.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Cariboo Indian Residential School dated October 28, 1939:

I had an opportunity to see the children and the school in its ordinary condition and without any special preparation for such an inspection.

The conditions were just the same as when notice is given of my intended inspection.

The new Principal is not a young man. I hope that he will be able to conduct this very old school in as efficient a manner as the Rev. G. Forbes did, but I somewhat doubt it. He had no assistant Priest at the school when I visited it. All the Priests were away on Missions, with the exception of the Principal of course.

While the actual classroom work is much the same as on the occasion of my last visit, I was not very much impressed with what I saw on the boys' side.

A large number of small boys were playing about without supervision around 9 a.m. when I think they should have been doing useful work of some kind. In the ordinary way on any other day of the week they would have been probably in the schoolroom. The girls were in the laundry at this time. The boys' disciplinarian was unsheaved. I am told that he is very good with the boys. His manner in my opinion is far from good. He is inclined to shout at the boys working.

I explained to the Reverend Principal that the Department held him responsible for the proper administration of his school, and that he was responsible for any corporal punishment of the children, no matter by whom administered.

I certainly hope that we shall not hear of any undue roughness with the children here.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B. C.

General Report
Cariboo Residential Indian School
Principal: Rev. Father J. McGrath

Vocational Education

Two notable improvements were made during the past year in conditions relating to pupils' tasks outside the classroom. The first was the renting of a saw for a few days last fall and the sawing of a considerable quantity of wood. The boys were thus relieved of much hard labor. The second was the installing of the clothes-washer purchased before my last visit, and the consequent lightening of the girls' labor.

The Principal has in mind plans for the better use of the time saved by these improvements. For the boys he plans, and indeed has already organized, courses in carpentry. He is also thinking of organizing boys' milk-cattle clubs. Later in the season he hopes to interest the girls in gardening.

If properly executed, these projects should be very valuable. Proper execution involves, I think, the following features:

(1) Pupil participation in planning.
(2) A thorough understanding of, and an interest in, the purposes served by each project and the principles underlying it. (A mere mechanical performance of set tasks will yield meager results).
(3) The correlation of the classroom courses, particularly science courses, with the projects.

Fire Protection

The fire-protection in the plant as a whole is inadequate. The water-pressure is low; fire-extinguishers and water carried in pails would have to be relied on to extinguish a blaze.

There are still ordinary locks on the fire-escape doors and the girls' door was locked when I inspected it. Outside of these doors are porches, the doors of which are firmly secured by hooks. There appears to be a grave danger that in case of fire at night pupils would pile up against these doors and be trampled, suffocated, or burned. The hazards are particularly serious in the girls' dormitory.
Cariboo Residential Indian School

Dormitories

Although the floors in the girls' dormitory are rough, conditions generally are satisfactory. The bedclothes are clean and the beds fairly comfortable.

As much cannot be said of the boys' dormitory. The springs of many of the beds are sagging almost to the floor, the bedclothes are dirty, and the odor which meets one at the door is anything but pleasant.

Dining Room and Food

I have heard no complaints regarding food in this institution. It appears to be plentiful and fairly adequate in other respects. The supply of apples is this year more plentiful than last. Meals are carefully supervised.

Water Supply

A supply of water is piped in from the hills. It is filtered before being used.

General Conditions

Plant. For reasons which I have mentioned in previous reports, I regard this plant as wholly unsuitable for present school needs. I think that the time has come for the Indian Department either to close this institution and establish day schools in the villages, or to acquire the land on which the buildings stand and erect a modern plant.

Classroom Program and Procedures

As I have indicated in my reports on individual teachers, there appear to be few marked changes in the character of the teaching since last year. There is, I think, a slight tendency toward more freedom and informality in the classroom, but it is far from certain that much of the work done in grades III to VI is still unrelated to the children's experience and is almost meaningless to them. The discussion of pictures shown in the assembly hall is valuable...

only one of the general proposals that I made last year for the improvement of classroom instruction has been carried out. These proposals were: (1) the division of the primary division into two parts for at least part of the year; (2) the making arrangements for the sisters to visit the Williams Lake school; (3) the providing of more supplementary books; and (4) the reading of some professional books by the teachers.

A few supplementary books—a stock which in any B.C. provincial school would be regarded as insignificant—have been purchased.

I am myself partly responsible for the fact that my last proposal met with no response: I neglected to supply the principal with the names of a few professional books and magazines.
Recreational activities. During the past two years there has been a notable improvement in the providing of facilities for recreation. Action pictures are shown every two weeks and are later discussed in the classrooms. Ice rinks have been made for both boys and girls and are used regularly. The pupils play basketball. Evening entertainments are held from time to time. Instruments for a pipe-and-drum band and some brass instruments as well have been purchased, and, when leaders become available, will be used.

For the organizing of all these activities the Principal has been mainly responsible, and should, I think, be highly commended.

Repairs. The Principal hopes before long to have in operation a saw which will produce rough lumber, much of which is badly needed for many purposes—among others construction of bookshelves in the classrooms.

H. MacArthur,
Inspector of Schools.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY

EDUCATION:

The Caribou Indian Residential School opened on September 1st and the Anaham Indian Day School on September 4th, 1945. The return of the pupils to the Residential School was much better this year. It was expected that there would have been very poor attendance at the Anaham Indian Day School during September due to the fact that most of the Indians were still having away from the main reserve, but a special effort was made to get their children back in time and practically all the pupils who attended last year are now back.

There are now fourteen pupils in the senior room and they show a very keen competitive spirit. Sr. Mary of the Angels, teacher of the senior room, visited St. Mary's school at Mission last year and saw the Pro-rec. work; and now has her pupils started on this type of physical education.

During the Indian Commissioner's visit, a site was chosen for a new school on this reserve, and, as soon as it is possible to get a representative meeting, the Indians will be asked to surrender this land to the Department for school purposes.

The Roman Catholic Church has not yet found a teacher for the Alexis Creek Day School, but Fr. Hennessy will, in all probability, fill for the winter months, i.e., November to March. With the erection of a school and living quarters, it may be possible to get the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King to supply a teacher for this school next year.

It was thought that there might be great difficulty in getting new pupils for the Cariboo Indian Residential School this season due to the non-payment of family Allowance to pupils attending Residential Schools, and, although the principal advises me that he is ten pupils short of the number provided for by the Department in the grant, there
EDUCATION

It is presumed that the grading of pupils in Indian schools should correspond to the standard of grades in white schools. If this is the case, I am of the opinion that the grading is too high at the Cariboo Residential School, since the five pupils transferred from that institution to the Anaham Indian Day School, two who had completed one year in Grade 6 were put back in Grade 4, the teacher of the senior room at Anaham advising me they were unable to do the work.

One of the drawbacks to Indian education in this Agency has been due to the fact that Indian parents would not, in most cases, send their children until they were 10 to 12 years old, and, therefore, they never got very far. Dear Mr. Phelan,

I have just returned after being three months in the West, during which time I visited all our B.C. Indian Schools with the exception of Kakawis. Unfortunately an attack of bronchitis prevented me from taking that trip.

I feel that I should draw your attention to the hard struggle that most of these schools are experiencing in order to make ends meet from the financial angle, and I am respectfully asking you to submit this matter to the Department for their very urgent consideration.

Williams Lake School in particular is in a very bad way. Already there is a large overdraft at the Bank, even though all the salaries on the part of the Fathers and Brothers have been eliminated. With the cost of living mounting to such high proportions it is impossible to finance a school on the present per capita grant. I am not in a position to carry the overdraft that I can see will be on the books by the end of the present school year. It seems to me that, unless some financial assistance is forthcoming to help to meet this crisis, we shall be obliged to close down the school.

There is another point upon which I beg you to give particular attention, and that is the electric plant now working in Williams Lake school. During the days that I spent there it was practically impossible to read by the light produced. The enclosed letter from the Principal, which has reached me since my return, speaks far more eloquently than I can upon the haunting fear that I had during my stay, namely should fire break out!

During my stay in the West I was, shall I say
amused, but at the same time annoyed, as I listened to a broadcast put on from the Vancouver Radio Station concerning Indian affairs. The speakers on the broadcast were Chief Michael of Lillooet, Mr. Guy Williams, President of the Native Brotherhood together with another speaker. There is no doubt that such broadcasts are doing considerable harm to the reputation of the Indian Department, because there seems to be no one authorized to reply to the very false charges made over the air. Perhaps I am going too far in suggesting that the Department should ask for a copy of the script of the Broadcast that was put over from Vancouver some weeks ago. I immediately called Father O'Grady's attention to it and suggested that he should get in touch with the Commissioner. One of the statements made in that broadcast, and naturally believed, because not contradicted, was the Indian schools did not teach the Indian child anything beyond the third or fourth grade.

With my kind regards,

Believe me, dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) J. Scannell, O.M.I.,
Provincial.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am in receipt of a letter from the Bishop of Kamloops in which he asks me to bring to your attention the serious situation of the schools and other educational facilities carried on by the various Catholic orders throughout the Cariboo. The Bishop has drawn to my attention, especially, the condition of the Indian residential school at 15C Mile House, and the day schools at Redstone Meadows and Anaham Indian Reserve, near Hanceville and Alexis Creek respectively.

I myself have visited the school at 15C Mile House and can vouch for the dilapidated condition of the buildings and the fact that they constitute a very serious fire hazard. The Oblate Fathers have found that they are unable to carry on the task of education and to repair, renovate and renew buildings as they should be. The result is that while they have striven for years to keep the buildings up, they have seen them going steadily behind, with constantly increasing regret until they are now practically forced to the conclusion that they cannot continue under present circumstances. This is not to mention the heating and lighting arrangements, which are utterly inadequate.

At Anaham Indian Reserve the Department has apparently accepted the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King as teachers, social workers and nurses, and I understand has undertaken to build a day school there. At present, the Sisters are forced to use the old community hall as a school. This is an old log building
totally unfit for the purpose, and it seems an injustice to accept the services of the Sisters and expect them to continue under these circumstances.

Much the same situation prevails at Redstone Meadows—the church is used as a school there, which is inadequate for the purpose.

In general, it is felt that the work of education in the Williams Lake Agency lags far behind those in other agencies throughout the province. The Bishop states that he fully recognizes and appreciates the splendid facilities which have been made available, for instance, at Kamloops (although there are still certain improvements which could be made, as outlined by Father O'Grady in a brief presented to the Indian Affairs Committee last year), and from my knowledge of these circumstances and of those prevailing in the Cariboo, I am able to appreciate his feeling that the two areas are not to be compared.

I would appreciate very much the favour of advice from you as to what may be intended to be done, if anything, to remedy the situation throughout the Williams Lake Agency with respect to educational facilities there.

Yours very truly,

E. D. Fulton

Ottawa, March 30, 1948.

Dear Mr. Fulton:

I received your letter of March 20th with reference to the education of Indian children in the Cariboo district.

We have recently supplied a new lighting plant and at the present time certain wiring is being done to the Cariboo Residential School at 150 Mile House. We hope to have funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49 for additional repairs.

We also propose to erect a new day school at Anaham Lake during the coming summer.

I appreciate the interest you are taking in Indian educational work in the Cariboo district and I can assure you that the representations that you have made will receive our very careful consideration.

Yours sincerely,
